{{Infobox language family |name=Greater Awyu |altname=Digul River |region=[[New Guinea]] |familycolor=Papuan |fam1=[[Trans–New Guinea languages|Trans–New Guinea]] |fam2=[[Central West New Guinea languages|Central West New Guinea]] |fam3=Awyu–Ok<ref>[https://sites.google.com/site/newguineaworld/families/trans-new-guinea/central-west-new-guinea/digul-river-ok New Guinea World, Digul River – Ok]</ref> |child1=Awyu–Dumut |child2=Becking–Dawi |child3=Sawi |glotto=grea1275 |glottorefname=Greater Awyu |map=Awyu-Dumut languages.svg |mapcaption=Map: The Awyu–Dumut languages of New Guinea {{legend|#FF5E5F|The Awyu–Dumut languages (other languages not shown)}} {{legend|#7BB5B6|Other Trans–New Guinea languages}} {{legend|#D9D9D9|Other Papuan languages}} {{legend|#E09D00|Austronesian languages}} {{legend|white|Uninhabited}} }}
The '''Greater Awyu''' languages, known in earlier and more limited classifications as '''Awyu–Dumut''' or '''Awyu–Ndumut''', and also known by the geographical label of '''Digul River''' languages, are a family of perhaps a dozen [[Trans–New Guinea languages]] spoken in eastern [[West Papua (region)|West Papua]]. Six of the languages are sufficiently attested for a basic description; it is not clear how many of the additional names (in parentheses below) may be separate languages.
==Classification== The classification below is based on Usher<ref>[https://sites.google.com/site/newguineaworld/families/trans-new-guinea/central-west-new-guinea/digul-river-ok/digul-river]</ref> and de Vries et al. (2012),<ref>Lourens de Vries, Ruth Wester, & Wilco van den Heuvel. 2012. "The Greater Awyu language family of West Papua", pp. 269–312 of Hammarström & van den Heuvel (eds.), ''History, Contact and Classification of Papuan Languages.'' (Language and Linguistics in Melanesia Special Issue). Port Moresby: Linguistic Society of Papua New Guinea.</ref> who used morphological innovations to determine relatedness, as these can be obscured by loans.
* [[Sawi language (Papuan)|Sawi]] (Sawuy) *Awyu–Dumut (Central Digul River) ** Awyu branch: [[Aghu language|Aghu]] (Jair), [[Shiaxa language|Shiaxa]] (Jenimu, Edera), [[Pisa language|Pisa]] (Asuwe) **Ndeiram–Ndumut *** Dumut (Wambon) branch: [[Mandobo language|Mandobo]] (Kaeti, Dumut), [[Wambon language|Wambon]] ***Ndeiram River: [[Kombai language|Kombai–Wanggom]] *North Digul River **[[Awbono-Bayono language|Awbono-Bayono]] **Becking–Dawi ***Dawi River: [[Komyandaret language|Komyandaret]], [[Tsaukambo language|Tsaukambo]] ***Becking River: [[Korowai language|Korowai]]
Sawi is classified on pronominal data, as the morphological data used for the rest of the family is not available. The pronouns of the Awyu–Dumut branch are:
:{| ! !!sg!!pl |- !1 |*nu-p||*na-gu-p |- !2 |*gu-p||*ga-gu-p |- !3 |*e-p, *[n]ege-p, *yu-p||*ya-gu-p |} The suffix *-p and the change of the final TNG *a vowel to *u do not appear in the possessive pronouns: ''*na, *ga, *ya/wa, *na-ga, *ga-ga, *ya-ga''.
Various other languages can be found in the literature. Ario (Sumagaxe)<ref>Multitree [http://multitree.org/codes/qgz qgz]</ref> is listed in Wurm, Foley, etc., but not in the University of Amsterdam survey and has been dropped by ''Ethnologue''. ''Ethnologue'' lists a 'Central Awyu', but this is not attested as a distinct language (U. Amsterdam). In general, the names in ''Ethnologue'' are quite confused, and older editions speak of names from Wurm (1982), such as ''Mapi, Kia, Upper Digul, Upper Kaeme'', which are names of language surveys along the rivers of those names, and may actually refer to [[Ok languages]] rather than to Awyu.
van den Heuvel & Fedden (2014) argue that Greater Awyu and Greater Ok are not genetically related, but that their similarities are due to intensive contact.<ref>van den Heuvel, W. & Fedden, S. (2014). Greater Awyu and Greater Ok: Inheritance or Contact? ''Oceanic Linguistics'' 53(1), 1-36. University of Hawai'i Press.</ref>
==History== The Awyu (pronounced like English ''Ow you'') and Awyu–Dumut families were identified by [[Peter Drabbe]] in the 1950s.
Voorhoeve included them in his proposed [[Central and South New Guinea languages|Central and South New Guinea]] group.<ref>Voorhoeve, C.L. 1968. “The Central and South New Guinea Phylum: a report on the language situation in south New Guinea. Pacific Linguistics, Series A, No. 16: 1-17. Canberra: Australian National University.</ref> As part of Central and South New Guinea, they form part of the original proposal for Trans–New Guinea.<ref>McElhanon, Kenneth A.and C.L. Voorhoeve. 1970. <u>The Trans-New Guinea phylum: explorations in deep-level genetic relationships.</u> Pacific Linguistics, Series B, No. 16. Canberra: Australian National University.</ref>

The '''Hela''' are a [[Sunni]] [[Muslim]] community found in the state of [[Rajasthan]] in [[India]].<ref name="Rajasthan">{{cite book | title =and madhyapradesh People of India: Rajasthan: Volume XXXVIII, Part One | editor = K.S. Singh | pages = 422–425 | publisher = Popular Prakashan | date = 1998-04-01 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=iKsqzB4P1ioC&pg=PA422 | isbn = 978-8171547661 }}</ref>
==Origin==
The Hela are a community of musicians. They claim to have come from [[Arabia]], sometime in the distant past. The Hela are found in the districts of udaipur [[Bundi]], [[Kota district|Kota]], [[Tonk district|Tonk]] and [[Jhalawar]]. They speak the Hadoti dialect of [[Hindi]]. The Hela are strictly endogamous, and marry close kin.<ref name="Rajasthan"/>
==Present== Their traditional occupation was musicians,instrumentalists,singers etc. Many are now employed in govt sector. They are a landless community, and many are employed as wage labourers. Now Hela lives in udaipur ujjain bundi dhar susner The Hela are well versed inragas such as dadri and thumri, but practice many folk beliefs.

{{For|the British politician|Ken Foster}} [[File:EllisUnitTX.jpg|thumb|The [[Ellis Unit]] housed the State of Texas death row for men until mid-1999.]] [[File:PolunskyUnitWestLivingstonTX.jpg|thumb|[[Allan B. Polunsky Unit]] houses the State of Texas death row for men.]] '''Kenneth Foster, Jr.''' (born October 22, 1976) is a prisoner formerly on [[death row]] in [[Capital punishment in Texas|Texas]], convicted under the [[Felony murder rule (Texas)|law of parties]]. He was convicted of murdering Michael LaHood in August 1996. His conviction and execution were contested because he was convicted under the Texas [[Law_of_Parties_(Texas)|Law of Parties]], not for physically committing the crime.
Foster, [[Texas Department of Criminal Justice]] (TDCJ) death row #999232, was received on death row on July 1, 1997.<ref>"[https://web.archive.org/web/20011126030807/http://www.tdcj.state.tx.us/statistics/deathrow/drowlist/fosterk.jpg fosterk.jpg]." [[Texas Department of Criminal Justice]]. Retrieved on April 15, 2016.</ref> He was initially located in the [[Ellis Unit]], but was transferred to the [[Allan B. Polunsky Unit]] (formerly the Terrell Unit) in 1999.<ref name="Drowfacts">"[http://www.tdcj.state.tx.us/death_row/dr_facts.html Death Row Facts]." [[Texas Department of Criminal Justice]]. Retrieved on February 4, 2016.</ref>
[[Governor of Texas|Texas Governor]] [[Rick Perry]] [[Commutation of sentence|commuted]] the [[Capital punishment|death sentence]] to [[life imprisonment]] only six hours before the execution was [[Execution warrant|scheduled to take place]] on August 30, 2007. Foster will be eligible for parole in 2036. He is currently incarcerated at the [[Stiles Facility]] of the [[Texas Department of Criminal Justice]] and is assigned to the facility's administrative segregation.

{{Infobox criminal | name = Lucas John Helder | image_name = LucasHelder.jpg | image_size = | image_caption = Helder's FBI mugshot | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|mf=yes|1981|05|05}} | birth_place = [[Pine Island, Minnesota]] | death_date = | death_place = | education = | occupation = [[Student]] | spouse = | charge = Mailbox [[pipe bomb]]ing | conviction_penalty = | conviction_status = Incompetent to stand trial, [[Involuntary commitment|committed to Federal Bureau of Prisons mental health center]] | parents = | children = }} '''Lucas John "Luke" Helder''' (born May 5, 1981) is a former [[University of Wisconsin–Stout]] student from [[Pine Island, Minnesota]], who earned notoriety as the '''Midwest Pipe Bomber''' in May 2002. == Bombings == While attending the [[University of Wisconsin–Stout]] and living in an apartment in [[Menomonie, Wisconsin]], Helder planned to plant [[pipe bomb]]s in mailboxes across the United States to create a [[smiley]] face shape on the United States map.{{cite news|url=http://tpr.org/post/who-might-be-behind-austin-bombings|title=Who Might Be Behind The Austin Bombings?|date=March 20, 2018|work=Texas Public Radio|accessdate=21 March 2018}} The bombs, which were packed with [[BB gun|BB]]s and [[Nail (fastener)|nails]], were rigged to explode as the mailboxes were opened. Completed and rigged bombs were found in [[Nebraska]], [[Colorado]], [[Texas]], [[Illinois]] and [[Iowa]]. In Iowa, six people, including four mail carriers, were injured when the bombs detonated.{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = United States Postal Service | title = 2002 Annual Report of Investigations: Violent Crime | work = USPS Website | publisher = | year = 2002 | url = http://www.usps.com/postalinspectors/ar02/ar02_04.htm | accessdate = 2007-10-16 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070926231308/http://www.usps.com/postalinspectors/ar02/ar02_04.htm |archivedate = 2007-09-26}} Ultimately, Helder planted 18 bombs and covered 3,200 miles.Reaves, Jessica. "Person of the Week: Lucas Helder." ''Time'' May 9, 2002 [http://www.time.com/time/pow/article/0,8599,236525,00.html] He was eventually captured in rural [[Nevada]] before he managed to complete the full smile. At the time of his arrest, police were looking for an unknown suspect driving a black [[Honda Accord]] and newspapers reported that he was wearing a [[Kurt Cobain]] T-shirt.{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = Leader-Telegram staff and The Associated Press | title = Dad aids son's capture | work = Leader-Telegram | publisher = Eau Claire Press Company | year = 2002 | url = http://www.leadertelegram.com/SpecialReports/Helder/5-8mainstory.asp | accessdate = 2007-10-16}} The bombings were heavily covered by the [[United States]] [[News media (United States)|media]]. == Writings and theories == [[File:Helder.jpg|right|thumb|150px|Helder performing with ''Apathy'' in his hometown of [[Pine Island, Minnesota]]]] While Helder was not at the top of his college class, his teachers described him as a reasonably good, quiet and polite student, and at first there was confusion as to what the motivation for the bombings could be. Within the year prior to his arrest, Helder had become passionate about [[astral projection]] techniques and came to believe that death of the flesh and body is not the end of existence, as evidenced by the [[manifesto]] he sent to ''[[The Badger Herald]]'' of the [[University of Wisconsin–Madison]] at the beginning of the bombing spree. The essay also includes statements such as
"I'm taking very drastic measure in attempt to provide this information to you... I will die/change in the end for this, but that's ok, hahaha paradise awaits! I'm dismissing a few individuals from reality, to change all of you for the better"{{cite news|url=http://www.thesmokinggun.com/file/luke-helder-manifesto|title=Pipe Bomb Suspect's Grungy Past|date=May 7, 2002|work=The Smoking Gun|accessdate=21 March 2018}}Lagorio, Christine. "News Analysis: Newspapers receipt of shady mail a daily occurrence." ''The Badger Herald'' May 10, 2002
Notes attached to the bombs went on to denounce [[government]] control over daily lives, deny that anyone who had died was really dead, and promised more of the same kind of message. == Trial == In April 2004, a federal judge found Helder incompetent to stand trial.{{cite web | last = Van Hyfte | first = Vanessa | authorlink = | title = Helder not fit to stand trial | work = WQAD Report | publisher = | year = 2004 | url = http://www.wqad.com/Global/story.asp?s=1756862 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20070927222552/http://www.wqad.com/Global/story.asp?s=1756862 |archive-date = 2007-09-27 |accessdate = 2018-03-21 }} While a judge could free Helder if doctors find he is not a threat to society, legal experts doubt this possibility due to the violent nature of his crimes. He has been diagnosed with [[schizoaffective disorder]].{{cite web|title=Victim of mailbox bombing hopes suspect gets well|website=Post Bulletin|url=http://www.postbulletin.com/news/crime/victim-of-mailbox-bombing-hopes-suspect-gets-well/article_38882ddd-c1ee-5871-ac03-9ede3085f5d1.html|last=Foley|first=Ryan|date=2013-05-18|accessdate=2017-01-31}} In 2013, a federal judge ordered Helder re-evaluated for competency to stand trial.{{cite news|url=https://www.twincities.com/2013/05/15/minnesotan-in-2002s-smiley-face-bomber-case-could-finally-face-trial/|title=Minnesotan in 2002’s ‘smiley face bomber’ case could finally face trial|last=staff|date=May 15, 2013|work=Twin Cities Pioneer Press|accessdate=21 March 2018}} Helder remains incarcerated in the [[FMC Rochester|Federal Medical Center]] in [[Rochester, Minnesota]].{{cite web|last= |first=Vanessa |authorlink=The Associated Press |title=Experts say mailbox bomb suspect unlikely to be freed soon |work=WQAD Report |publisher= |date=April 6, 2004 |url=http://www.wqad.com/Global/story.asp?s=1767322 |accessdate=2007-10-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927222627/http://www.wqad.com/Global/story.asp?s=1767322 |archivedate=September 27, 2007 |df= }} == Musical background == Prior to his bombing spree, Helder was a member of Apathy, a [[Rochester, Minnesota]], three-piece [[grunge]] band. Although the band was successful only on a local scale, it recorded a CD named ''Sacks of People'' at the end of their first summer together, which they funded and released themselves. When the news broke that Helder was the pipe bomber, the media made significant mention of his status as a musician.{{cite web|last=Feldman |first=Charles |authorlink= |title=Feds: Suspect admitted pipe bomb spree. |work=CNN.com |publisher= |date=May 9, 2002 |url=http://archives.cnn.com/2002/US/05/08/mailbox.pipebombs/index.html |accessdate=2007-10-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071117123142/https://archives.cnn.com/2002/US/05/08/mailbox.pipebombs/index.html |archivedate=November 17, 2007 |df= }} Many music critics scrambled to acquire copies of Apathy's CD, some of which were auctioned on [[eBay]] for as much as $200. == See also == *[[Improvised explosive device]] *[[Ted Kaczynski]] *[[Austin serial bombings]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.wqad.com/global/Story.asp?s=1261206 Timeline of Helder's news]{{Dead link|date=May 2012}}, [[WQAD-TV]] * [http://www.thesmokinggun.com/archive/lukehelder1.html The Smoking Gun archive on Luke Helder, with the six-page manifesto] {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Helder, Luke}} [[Category:1981 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Pine Island, Minnesota]] [[Category:University of Wisconsin–Stout alumni]] [[Category:American criminals]] [[Category:American people imprisoned on charges of terrorism]] [[Category:American people of Dutch descent]] [[Category:Guitarists from Minnesota]] [[Category:Bombers (people)]] [[Category:People acquitted by reason of insanity]] [[Category:Explosions in 2002]] [[Category:Improvised explosive device bombings in the United States]] [[Category:People from Menomonie, Wisconsin]]

'''Männerchor''' or '''Maennerchor''' ({{IPA-de|ˈmɛnɐˌkoːɐ̯}}, "men's chorus") is the name given to [[German language|German]] [[social clubs]], primarily in the northeastern [[United States]], [[Pennsylvania]] in particular. The earliest forms of these clubs where "singing societies" that perpetuated traditional [[choral]] music, both German and [[German American|German-American]] culture, providing ''[[Gemuetlichkeit]]'' for new immigrants. Such clubs are typically attended by men and many function as a restaurant and bar, serving [[German cuisine|German food]]s and [[Beer in Germany|beer]]s.
A Maennerchor was established in [[Cincinnati]] in 1857 with the merging of the Liedertafel, the Saengerbund and the Germanic Societies;<ref>{{cite web | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-hB6AAAAMAAJ&dq=cincinnati%20the%20queen%20city%20clarke&pg=PA465#v=onepage&q=cincinnati%20the%20queen%20city%20clarke&f=false | title=Cincinnati, the Queen City, 1788-1912, Volume 2 | publisher=The S. J. Clarke Publishing Company | date=1912 | accessdate=2013-05-20 | author=Clark, S. J. | pages=465}}</ref> it was the oldest musical organization of the city.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eJxABLtxX60C&dq=1880%20cincinnati&pg=PA879#v=onepage&q&f=false | title=Centennial History of Cincinnati and Representative Citizens, Volume 1 | publisher=Biographical Publishing Company | date=1904 | accessdate=2013-05-22 | author=Charles Theodore Greve | pages=879}}</ref> The [[Indianapolis Maennerchor]]. founded in 1854 in [[Indianapolis]], [[Indiana]], is another such organization.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www-lib.iupui.edu/special/collections/german-american/mss040 |title=Indianapolis Maennerchor Records, 1866-1990 |publisher=[[IUPUI University Library]] |date= |accessdate=2013-11-28}}</ref>
The [[Damenchor]] often serves as the Maennerchor auxiliary for women.
==List of examples== *Erie Maennerchor, in [[Erie, Pa.]] *[[Indianapolis Maennerchor]] *[[Germania Männerchor]], [[Chicago]] *[[Teutonia Maennerchor Hall|Teutonia Maennerchor]], [[Pittsburgh]] *[[Germania Männerchor Volksfest]], [[Evansville, Indiana]] *[[Cleveland Maennerchor]], [[Cleveland, Ohio]] *[[Harrisburg Maennerchor]], [[Harrisburg, Pennsylvania]] *[[Norristown Maennerchor]], [[Norristown, Pennsylvania]]

{{redirect|Darja|the village in Iran|Darreh Ja|the Romanian village of Dârja|Panticeu}} {{Infobox language |name=Maghrebi Arabic |altname=Darija |region=[[Maghreb]] |familycolor=Afro-Asiatic |fam2=[[Semitic languages|Semitic]] |fam3=[[Central Semitic languages|Central Semitic]] |fam4=[[Arabic]] |script=[[Arabic alphabet]], [[Romanization of Arabic|Latin alphabet]] |glotto=nort3191 |glottorefname=North African Arabic }} '''Maghrebi Arabic''' ('''Western Arabic'''; as opposed to Eastern Arabic or [[Mashriqi Arabic]]) is an [[Arabic]] [[Varieties of Arabic|dialect continuum]] spoken in the [[Maghreb]] region, in [[Morocco]], [[Algeria]], [[Tunisia]], [[Libya]], [[Western Sahara]], and [[Mauritania]]. It includes [[Moroccan Arabic|Moroccan]], [[Algerian Arabic|Algerian]], [[Tunisian Arabic|Tunisian]], [[Libyan Arabic|Libyan]], and [[Hassaniya Arabic]]. Speakers of Maghrebi Arabic call their language '''Derja''', '''Derija''' or '''Darija''' ({{lang-ar|الدارجة}}; meaning "to rise or advance step by step"<ref>{{cite book|last1=Wehr|first1=Hans|title=A Dictionary of Modern Written Arabic: (Arab.-Engl.)|date=1979|publisher=Otto Harrassowitz Verlag|isbn=3447020024|page=319|url=https://www.google.com/books?id=WTak55pG-_IC&pg=PA319|accessdate=30 September 2017}}</ref>). This serves to differentiate the spoken vernacular from [[Modern Standard Arabic]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Harrell|first1=Richard Slade|title=A Dictionary of Moroccan Arabic: Moroccan-English|date=2004|publisher=Georgetown University Press|isbn=1589011031|page=18|url=https://www.google.com/books?id=uQD2Qd-dhy0C&pg=PA18|accessdate=30 September 2017}}</ref> As the [[Maltese language]] is believed to have been immediately derived from [[Siculo-Arabic]] and ultimately from Tunisian Arabic, it contains some typical Maghrebi Arabic areal characteristics.<ref>{{cite book|authors=Marie Azzopardi-Alexander, Albert Borg|title=Maltese|date=2013|publisher=Routledge|isbn=1136855289|page=xiii|url=https://www.google.com/books?id=80S7B0sAKFIC&pg=PR13|accessdate=10 January 2018}}</ref>
==Varieties== [[File:Arabic Dialects.svg|thumb|right|An overview of the different [[varieties of Arabic]]. Maghrebi varieties are shades of blue.]] * [[Varieties of Arabic]] * [[Pre-Hilalian Arabic dialects]] * [[Hilalian dialects]] * [[Koiné language|Koinés]]: ** [[Algerian Arabic]] ** [[Moroccan Arabic]] ** [[Tunisian Arabic]] ** [[Libyan Arabic]] ** [[Jebli Arabic]] ** [[Jijel Arabic]] ** [[Andalusian Arabic]] (extinct) ** [[Siculo-Arabic]] (extinct) *** [[Maltese language]] (descended from Sicilian Arabic, but influenced [[lexicon|lexically]] by Tunisian, Libyan, Sicilian, Italian, French, and more recently, English) * Western [[Bedouin]]: ** [[Hassānīya|Hassaniya Arabic]] ** [[Saharan Arabic]]
==Name== ''Darija'', ''Derija'' or ''Delja'' ({{lang-ar|الدارجة}}) means "everyday/colloquial language";<ref>Wehr, Hans: ''Dictionary of Modern Written Arabic'' (2011); Harrell, Richard S.: ''Dictionary of Moroccan Arabic'' (1966)</ref> it is also rendered as ''{{transl|aeb|ed-dārija}}'', ''derija'' or ''darja''. It refers to any of the varieties of colloquial Maghrebi Arabic. Although it is also common in [[Algeria]] and [[Tunisia]] to refer to the Maghrebi Arabic varieties directly as languages, similarly it is also common in [[Egypt]] and [[Lebanon]] to refer to the Mashriqi Arabic varieties directly as languages. For instance, Algerian Arabic would be referred as ''Dzayri'' (Algerian) and Tunisian Arabic as ''Tounsi'' (Tunisian), and Egyptian Arabic would be referred as ''Masri'' (Egyptian) and Lebanese Arabic as ''Lubnani'' (Lebanese).
In contrast, the colloquial dialects of more eastern Arab countries, such as Egypt, Jordan and Sudan, are usually known as ''{{transl|aeb|al-‘āmmīya}}'' ({{lang|ar|العامية}}), though Egyptians may also refer to their dialects as ''al-logha-d-darga''.
==Characteristics== The varieties of Maghrebi Arabic (Darija) have a significant degree of mutual intelligibility, especially between geographically adjacent ones (such as local dialects spoken in Eastern Morocco and Western Algeria or Eastern Algeria and North Tunisia or South Tunisia and Western Libya), but hardly between Moroccan and Tunisian Darija. Conversely, Moroccan Darija, Tunisian Derja and particularly Algerian Derja cannot be understood by Eastern Arabic speakers (from Egypt, Sudan, Levant, Iraq, and Arabian peninsula) in general as they derive from different substratums and a mixture of many languages (Berber, Latin ([[African Romance]]), Old Arabic, Turkish, French, Spanish, [[Mozarabic]], Italian, and Niger-Congo languages). Some [[linguists]] like [[Charles A. Ferguson]], [[William Marçais]] consider Maghrebi Arabic Darija an independent language.<ref> Abdou Elimam, « Le maghribi, langue trois fois millénaire », éd. ANEP, Alger (1997)</ref><ref>Abdou Elimam, « Le maghribi, alias ed-darija, langue consensuelle du Maghreb », éd. Dar El Gharb, Alger (2004)</ref>
Maghrebi Arabic continues to evolve by integrating new French or English words, notably in technical fields, or by replacing old French and Italian/Spanish ones with Modern Standard Arabic words within some circles; more educated and upper-class people who code-switch between Maghrebi Arabic and Modern Standard Arabic have more French and Italian/Spanish loanwords, especially the latter came from the time of [[al-Andalus]]. Maghrebi dialects all use ''n-'' as the [[grammatical person|first-person]] [[grammatical number|singular]] [[prefix (linguistics)|prefix]] on [[verb]]s, distinguishing them from [[Levantine Arabic|Levantine dialects]] and Modern Standard Arabic.
===Relationship with Modern Standard Arabic and Berber languages=== Modern Standard Arabic ({{lang|ar|الفصحى}} ''al-Fusḥā'') is the primary language used in the government, legislation and judiciary of countries in the Maghreb. Maghrebi Arabic is mainly a [[spoken language|spoken]] and [[vernacular language]], although it occasionally appears in entertainment and advertising in urban areas of Algeria, Morocco and Tunisia. In Algeria, where Maghrebi Arabic was taught as a separate subject under French colonization, some textbooks in the language exist but they are no longer officially endorsed by the Algerian authorities. Maghrebi Arabic contains a [[Berber languages|Berber]] [[stratum (linguistics)|substratum]], which represents the languages originally spoken by the native populations of the Maghreb prior to their adoption of Arabic.<ref name="Mohand">Tilmatine Mohand, « Substrat et convergences : Le berbère et l'arabe nord-africain », ''Estudios de dialectologia norteaafricana y andalusi'', n°4, 1999, pp. 99-119</ref> The dialect may also possess a [[Punic language|Punic]] substrate.<ref name="maghribi">{{cite journal|last=Benramdane|first=Farid|title=''Le maghribi, langue trois fois millénaire'' de ELIMAM, Abdou (Éd. ANEP, Alger 1997)|journal=Insaniyat|volume=|issue=6|date=1998|pages=129–130|issn=|url=http://insaniyat.revues.org/12102|accessdate=12 February 2015}}</ref> Additionally, Maghrebi Arabic has a [[Latin]] substratum, which may have been derived from the [[African Romance]] that was used as an urban lingua franca during the [[Byzantine Empire]] period.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Sayahi|first1=Lotfi|title=Diglossia and Language Contact: Language Variation and Change in North Africa|date=2014|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=0521119367|page=26|url=https://www.google.com/books?id=9R5GAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA26|accessdate=13 December 2017}}</ref>
===Relationship with foreign languages=== Maghrebi Arabic speakers frequently borrow words from French (in Morocco, Algeria and Tunisia), Spanish (in Morocco) and Italian (in Libya and Tunisia) and [[Grammatical conjugation|conjugate]] them according to the rules of their dialects with some exceptions (like passive voice for example). Since it is not always written, there is no standard and it is free to change quickly and to pick up new vocabulary from neighbouring languages. This is somewhat similar to what happened to [[Middle English]] after the [[Norman conquest]].
==See also== * [[Varieties of Arabic]] * [[Moroccan Arabic]] * [[Languages of Africa]]
==References== <references />
==Further reading== * Singer, Hans-Rudolf (1980) “Das Westarabische oder Maghribinische” in Wolfdietrich Fischer and Otto Jastrow (eds.) ''Handbuch der arabischen Dialekte''. Otto Harrassowitz: Wiesbaden. 249-76.

Coudert]] | main_organ = | parent_organization = | affiliations = | budget = | num_staff = | num_volunteers = | website = | remarks = | former name = }} The '''Manhattan Club''' was a social club in [[Manhattan]], New York founded in 1865 and dissolved around 1979. ==History== Designed to be the Democratic answer to the [[Union Club of the City of New York|Union Club]], its prominent members included [[Samuel J. Tilden]], [[August Belmont]], [[Grover Cleveland]], [[Alfred E. Smith]], [[Herbert H. Lehman]], [[Jimmy Walker]] and [[Robert F. Wagner]]{{cite news| title=MANHATTAN CLUB SOLD FOR $600,000 - Century-Old Institution Was Refuge for Democrats.|work=New York Times |date = 5 May 1965}} Other prominent members included [[Augustus Schell]], [[Dean Richmond]] and [[John T. Hoffman]].{{cite news|url= http://search.proquest.com/hnpnewyorktimes/docview/97673063/fulltextPDF/13F67D0CC1E452A60D5/1?accountid=34227| title=Famous Manhattan Club Is Fifty Years Old: Since Its Founding in 1865 the Noted Democratic Organization Has Many Times Played a Prominent Part in the History of New York.|work=New York Times |date= 10 October 1915}} In 1885 it was listed as the residence of [[Robert Roosevelt|Robert Barnwell Roosevelt]], the uncle of Theodore Roosevelt{{Cite journal|last=Harrington|first=James|date=December 1997|title=The New York Public Library97117The New York Public Library. Publisher address:: New York Public Library URL: http://www.nypl.org/|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1108/err.1997.1.12.136.117|journal=Electronic Resources Review|volume=1|issue=12|pages=136–137|doi=10.1108/err.1997.1.12.136.117|issn=1364-5137}}. The Manhattan Club was organized on September 25, 1865 at [[Delmonico's]] on 14th Street at Fifth Avenue. Its first home was the Benkard House at 96 Fifth Avenue near the corner of 15th Street (called "Old 96" by members), followed by the [[Alexander Turney Stewart#Fifth Avenue mansion|A.T. Stewart Mansion]] on 34th Street at Fifth Avenue.{{cite news|url= http://search.proquest.com/hnpnewyorktimes/docview/97673063/fulltextPDF/13F67D0CC1E452A60D5/1?accountid=34227| title=Famous Manhattan Club Is Fifty Years Old: Since Its Founding in 1865 the Noted Democratic Organization Has Many Times Played a Prominent Part in the History of New York.|work=New York Times |date= 10 October 1915}} From 1899 to 1966, it occupied the [[Jerome Mansion]], at which time the building was sold to a developer and subsequently was torn down.{{cite news| title=Time Running Out for City Landmark: 17-Month Search For Buyer for Jerome Mansion Fails.|work=New York Times |date = 22 May 1967}} The Manhattan Club then moved to a suite of rooms at the [[InterContinental New York Barclay Hotel|Barclay Hotel]] previously occupied by the [[Cornell Club]]{{cite news| title=News of Realty : Club Will Move - 101 Year Old Manhattan Gets Barclay Hotel Suite.|work=New York Times |date = 10 November 1966}} and thereafter functioned mainly as a luncheon club.{{cite news| title=For Luncheon Clubs, Food is of Secondary Importance.|work=New York Times |date = 23 April 1967}} Around 1979, its suites were converted into conference rooms and the Manhattan Club was closed.http://nealprince.omeka.net/items/show/108 ===Ambiguous Democratic Party Legacy=== Despite having been conceived as a [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]] bastion during the [[U.S. Civil War]], in its later days, the members of the Manhattan Club were often decidedly Republican in sympathies. In 1954, a survey of the men's social clubs of Manhattan noted that the club had become "ninety percent Republican."{{cite journal|url =http://www.andrewcusack.com/2008/08/14/the-great-club-revolution/| title=The Great Club Revolution - What with all this democracy things will never be the same |journal=[[American Heritage (magazine)|American Heritage]] |author=[[Cleveland Amory]] |date=December 1954}} A half-century earlier, the significant majority of members supported Republican [[William McKinley]]'s bid for President of the United States, triggering letters of resignation from members who wanted it to be a Democratic Club.{{cite news|url= https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=990DE1DE103BEE33A25752C1A9679D94679ED7CF| title=Col. Brown's Resignation - Correspondence with the Manhattan Club's President.|work=New York Times |date= 11 November 1896}} ==Invention of the Manhattan Cocktail== A popular history suggests that the Manhattan cocktail originated at the club in the early 1870s, where it was invented by Dr. Iain Marshall for a banquet hosted by [[Jennie Jerome]] (Lady Randolph Churchill, [[Winston Churchill|Winston]]'s mother) in honor of presidential candidate [[Samuel J. Tilden]]. The success of the banquet made the drink fashionable, later prompting several people to request the drink by referring to the name of the club where it originated—"the ''Manhattan'' cocktail".See [[Manhattan (cocktail)]] ==Painting by Childe Hassam == [[Image:The Manhattan Club (The Stewart Mansion) 1891.jpg|thumb|The Manhattan Club, 1891 painting by [[Childe Hassam]]]] The exterior of the club was featured in an 1891 painting by [[Childe Hassam]] when it was at the [[Alexander Turney Stewart#Fifth Avenue mansion|Stewart Mansion]]. ==Murder of Stanford White== On June 26, 1906, [[Stanford White]] was shot to death by [[Harry K. Thaw]], the eccentric millionaire, after leaving the Manhattan Club. The murder took place three blocks south in what was then [[Madison Square Garden]]. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{cite book|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=he8TAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA26&lpg=PA26&dq=%22douglas+taylor%22+new+york+sentinel&source=bl&ots=t_yU-Ie6M9&sig=QmXqY1arVOLiwPOkusVgM7WtS6Y&hl=en&sa=X&ei=YGqnVIAPjv-DBOnngtAM&ved=0CC4Q6AEwAg#v=onepage&q&f=false| title=History of the Manhattan Club: A Narrative of the Activities of Half a Century.|date=1915 |publisher= De Vinne Press |author=Henry Watterson}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Manhattan Club (social club)}} [[Category:Clubs and societies in the United States]] [[Category:Political history of New York City]] [[Category:Democratic Party (United States) organizations]] [[Category:1865 establishments in New York (state)]] [[Category:1979 disestablishments in New York (state)]]

{{distinguish|Mang language}} {{Infobox language |name=Mang |altname=Mashan Miao |nativename= |pronunciation={{IPA|mʱaŋ˨}} |states=[[China]] |region=[[Guizhou]] |ethnicity= |speakers={{sigfig|137,000|2}} |date=1995 |ref=e18 |familycolor=Hmong-Mien |fam2=[[Hmongic languages|Hmongic]] |fam3=[[West Hmongic]] |fam4= |lc1=hmm|ld1=Central |lc2=hmp|ld2=Northern |lc3=hma|ld3=Southern |lc4=hmw|ld4=Western |glotto=mash1238 |glottorefname=Mashan }} '''Mang''', or '''Mashan Miao''' also known as '''Mashan Hmong''' (麻山 ''máshān''), is a [[Miao languages|Miao language]] of China. The endonym is ''Mang'', similar to other [[West Hmongic languages]] such as [[Mong language|Mong]]. ==Varieties== Mang was classified as a branch of [[Western Hmongic]] in Wang (1985), who listed four varieties.王辅世主编，《苗语简志》，民族出版社，1985年。 Matisoff (2001) gave these four varieties the status of separate languages, and, conservatively, did not retain them as a single group within West Hmongic. Li Yunbing (2000) added two minor varieties which had been left unclassified in Wang, Southeastern (Strecker's "[[Luodian County|Luodian]] Muyin") and Southwestern ("[[Wangmo County|Wangmo]]").李云兵，《苗语方言划分遗留问题研究》，中央民族大学出版社，2000年。 *Central Mang: 70,000 speakers *Northern Mang: 35,000 *Western Mang: 14,000 *Southern Mang: 10,000 *Southeastern Mang: 4,000 *Southwestern Mang: 4,000 ==Phonology and script== A pinyin alphabet had been created for Mang in 1985, but proved to have deficiencies. Wu and Yang (2010) report the creation of a new alphabet, albeit a tentative one, based on the Central Mang dialect of [[Ziyun County]], ''Zōngdì'' 宗地 township, ''Dàdìbà'' 大地坝 village.Wú Zhèngbiāo and Yáng Guāngyīng, 2010. [https://web.archive.org/web/20150420085819/http://218.249.224.102/upfile/20115613035615353.pdf 麻山次方言区苗文方案的设计与使用——兼谈苗族英雄史诗《亚鲁王》的记译整理问题], 民族翻译.
Several consonants were added to the 1985 alphabet, while ''bz, pz, nbz, mz'' and ''gh'' were removed. Consonants, in pinyin, are: :labial: ''b p nb np, m f v, by py nby my, bl pl nbl npl ml'' :lateral: ''l lj'' :dental or alveolar stops: ''d t dl dj nd nt n'' :dental affricates: ''z c s nz nc'' :retroflex: ''dr tr ndr nr sh r'' :alveolo-palatal: ''j q nj x y ny'' :velar or uvular: ''g k ngg ng, h w hw'' :(zero onset) The Latin voiced/voiceless opposition has been coopted to indicate aspiration, as usual in pinyin alphabets. Correspondences between Central Mang dialects include Dadiba retroflex ''dr, tr'' with dental ''z, c'' in another village of the same Zongdi township, Sanjiao (三脚 ''Sānjiǎo''). The other five varieties of Mang have more palatalized initials than Central Mang, though these can be transcribed as medial ''-i-''. The onsets ''by, py, nby, my'' are pronounced {{IPA|[pʐ pʰʐ mpʐ mʐ ]}} in Central Mang and {{IPA|[pj pʰj mpj mj]}} in the other five Mang varieties. Vowels and finals, including those needed for Chinese loans, are: :''a aa'' {{IPA|[ã]}} ''ai ao ain ang :''e ea ei en ein eu ew eng :''i iou in ie iu iao ian iang :''o ou ow ong :''u uw ua ui ue un uai uan uang :''yu'' Most Central Mang and Western Mang dialects have eleven to thirteen [[tone (linguistics)|tones]]. Compared to the eight tone categories of other [[Western Hmongic]] languages, the odd-numbered tones are each split into two. The tones of at least three villages of Central Mang have been documented: Dadiba (Wu & Yang 2010), Jiaotuozhai (Wang & Mao 1995; Li 2000), and Jingshuiping (Xian 1990; Mortensen 2006Mortensen (2006), [http://www.pitt.edu/~drm31/VowelRaisingInShuijingping.pdf Diachronic Universals and Synchronic Parochialisms: Explaining Tone-Vowel Interactions].), all in the Zongdi township of [[Ziyun County]]. They lie several kilometers apart and have minor differences. {|class=wikitable |+ Central Mang tone !colspan=2|        !!Dadiba !! Jingshuiping !!Jiaotuozhai |- align=center !1a | ''-b'' |{{IPA|˦˨}} 42 |{{IPA|˧}} 3 |{{IPA|˧˨}} 32 |- align=center !1b | ''-p'' |colspan=3|{{IPA|˨}} 2 |- align=center ! 2 |''-x'' |{{IPA|˥}} 5 |{{IPA|˦˨}} 42 |{{IPA|˥˧}} 53 |- align=center !3a | ''-d'' |colspan=2|{{IPA|˥˧}} 53 |{{IPA|˦˨}} 42 |- align=center !3b | ''-z'' |colspan=3|{{IPA|˨˧˨}} 232 |- align=center !4 |''-l'' |colspan=3|{{IPA|˩}} 1 |- align=center !5a | ''-t'' |colspan=3|{{IPA|˥}} 55 |- align=center !5b |''-c'' |colspan=2|{{IPA|˨˦}} 24 |{{IPA|˧˥}} 35 |- align=center !6 | ''-s'' |colspan=3|{{IPA|˩˧}} 13 |- align=center !6' |''-p'' |colspan=2|{{IPA|˨}} 2 |{{IPA|˧}} 3 |- align=center !7a | ''-k'' |{{IPA|˧}} 3 |colspan=2|{{IPA|˦}} 4 |- align=center !7b |''-s'' |colspan=3|{{IPA|˩˧}} 13 |- align=center !8 |''-f'' |colspan=3|{{IPA|˨˩}} 21 |} Although some pairs of tones (such as tones 6 and 7b) have the same value when pronounced alone, they behave differently with regard to [[tone sandhi]] and should be treated as different phonologically. Tones also interact with phonation types and vowel quality. Jiaotuozhai tones 4 and 6 are breathy voiced and have higher vowels. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Hmong-Mien languages}} {{Languages of China}} [[Category:West Hmongic languages]] [[Category:Languages of China]]
