'''Patrol 36''' ({{lang-he|פטרול 36}}, {{IPA-he|paˈtrol ʃloˈʃim ve ˈʃeʃ|}}, {{lang-ru|Патруль 36}}, {{IPA-ru|pɐˈtrʊlʲ ˈtrɪjt͡sɐtʲ ˈʂɛstʲ|}}) was an [[Israelis|Israeli]] [[Neo-Nazism#Israel|neo-Nazi]] organization, consisting of 8 teenagers, led by Eli Bonite (born Erik Bunyatov in 1988), alias "Ely the Nazi" ({{lang-he|אלי הנאצי}} ''Eli ha-Natsi'', {{lang-ru|Нацист Эли}} ''Natsist Eli''). The group's members were [[Russian people|Russian]] immigrants aged 16 to 21. According to ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'', the men's families were allowed to settle in [[Israel]] under the [[Law of Return]], meaning that they all had at least one grandparent with a [[Jews|Jewish mother]], although none of them were Jewish according to the Jewish law.
==Activities==
The group desecrated buildings, especially synagogues, with [[swastika]]s and graffiti, and carried out attacks on migrant workers from Africa and Asia, drug addicts, gays, Ultra-Orthodox Jews, and elderly people. Patrol 36's members reportedly had tattoos with the number [[88 (number)|88]] (a reference to the phrase "Heil Hitler") and were stockpiling guns, [[trinitrotoluene|TNT]], knives and portraits of Adolf Hitler. The group produced videos of their own attacks, which were found on computers seized by police.<ref name="nazichic">{{cite news|url=http://blogs.telegraph.co.uk/news/damianthompson/100049486/nazi-chic-from-mongolia-to-tel-aviv-angry-teenagers-think-hitler-is-cool/|title=Nazi chic: from Mongolia to Tel Aviv, angry teenagers think Hitler is cool|accessdate=August 22, 2010|date=August 3, 2010|first=Damian|last=Thompson|publisher=The Telegraph|location=London}}</ref><ref name="jailtime">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/7744966.stm|accessdate=August 22, 2010|title=Jail terms for Israeli neo-Nazis |date=November 23, 2008|publisher=BBC News}}</ref><ref name="global">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/aug/02/global-reach-neo-nazis|title=The global reach of neo-Nazis|accessdate=August 22, 2010|date=August 2, 2010|publisher=The Guardian|location=London|first=Jason|last=Rodrigues}}</ref> <ref name="BBC Israeli">{{cite news|title=Israeli 'neo-Nazi gang' arrested|date=9 September 2007|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/6985808.stm|publisher=BBC}}</ref><ref name="Asser">{{cite news|title=Israeli anger over 'Nazi' group|author=Martin Asser|publisher=BBC|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/6987848.stm|date=10 September 2007}}</ref> <ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/6989776.stm |title=Middle East | Israeli neo-Nazi suspects charged |publisher=BBC News |date=2007-09-11 |accessdate=2009-11-03}}</ref> One of the group's members, Ivan Kuzmin, said that in "Russia they called me Dirty Jew, and here they called me Stinking Russian". He said that the racism he experienced turned him into a racist.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ezXm9jkukBo Israel's Neo Nazis- Israel] Journeyman Pictures, Israel's Neo-Nazis</ref>
Bonite was once recorded telling a gang member "my grandfather was a half-Jewboy. I will not have children so that this trash will not be born with even a tiny per cent of Jewboy blood."<ref>{{cite news|author=Conal Urquhart in Jerusalem |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2007/sep/10/israel.internationalcrime |title=Israeli neo-Nazi ring caught after attacks on synagogues | World news |publisher=The Guardian |date= 2007-09-10|accessdate=2012-08-21 |location=London}}</ref> The cell was based in [[Petah Tikva]], near [[Tel Aviv]], where they all lived.
==Arrest==
Israeli Police began investigating the group in 2006, after two incidents of Neo-Nazi graffiti in Petah Tikva. On September 9, 2007, seven of the group's members were arrested, while the leader, Erik Bonite, fled the country. Police also seized computers depicting videos of their attacks that they had filmed, Neo-Nazi related materials, such as swastika posters and Neo-Nazi films, along with explosives and an improvised pistol.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3447377,00.html |title=Israeli neo-Nazis arrested - Israel Jewish Scene, Ynetnews |publisher=Ynetnews.com |date= |accessdate=2012-08-21}}</ref><ref name="BBC Israeli"/> They were charged with conspiracy to commit a crime, assault, racial incitement, and distribution of racist materials, and tried in the Tel Aviv District Court. All eight were found guilty, and received sentences ranging between one and seven years in prison. While reading the verdict, Judge Tsvi Gurfinkel said that he was imposing severe penalties to deter anyone else from following their example.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/7744966.stm |title=Middle East | Jail terms for Israeli neo-Nazis |publisher=BBC News |date=2008-11-23 |accessdate=2012-08-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Angela Balakrishnan and agencies |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2008/nov/24/israelandthepalestinians |title=Jewish youths jailed for neo-Nazi attacks in Israel | World news | guardian.co.uk |publisher=Guardian |date= 2008-11-24|accessdate=2012-08-21 |location=London}}</ref> Erik Bonite received a seven-year prison term ''[[trial in absentia|in absentia]]''. In January 2011, he returned to Israel, and was arrested at the airport.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hrN2vJqK-RUrJyAwLVn4r4JTOdBA?docId=CNG.db6e69a39bc8bc4ed7a6f5bfacf1a7a4.941 |title=AFP: Israel arrests fugitive neo-Nazi leader: police |publisher=Google.com |date=2011-01-03 |accessdate=2012-08-21}}</ref>
==Reaction==
Their discovery led to renewed calls amongst politicians to amend the Law of Return.<ref name="Stoil">{{cite web|title=Sheetrit may deport alleged neo-Nazis|author=Rebecca Anna Stoil, Mark Weiss and Matthew Wagner|publisher=[[The Jerusalem Post]]|date=9 September 2007|accessdate=2007-09-10|url=http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?pagename=JPost/JPArticle/ShowFull&cid=1188392567423}}{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> [[Effi Eitam]] of the [[National Religious Party]] and the [[National Union (Israel)|National Union]], which represent the religious [[Zionism|Zionist]] movement and have previously attempted to advance bills to amend the Law of Return, stated that Israel has become "a haven for people who hate Israel, hate Jews, and exploit the Law of Return to act on this hatred."<ref name="Singer">{{cite web|title=Interior Minister: I'll consider revoking neo-Nazis' citizenship|author=Roni Singer-Heruti|publisher=[[Ha'aretz]]|date=10 September 2007|accessdate=2007-09-10|url=http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/902093.html}}</ref>
Judge Tsvi Gurfinkel, who issued the guilty verdict {{clarify|date=April 2016}}, said that "the fact that they are Jews from the ex-Soviet Union and that they had sympathised with individuals who believed in racist theories is terrible." [[BBC]] reported that the news of the attacks and of the men's arrests in 2007 "shocked the nation" because Israel was founded in the wake of the [[The Holocaust|Holocaust]]. One of the members who was arrested and sentenced was the grandson of a [[List of Holocaust survivors|Holocaust survivor]].<ref name="jailtime"/>

A '''planned unit development (PUD)''' is a type of building development and also a regulatory process. As a building development, it is a designed grouping of both varied and compatible [[land use]]s, such as [[house|housing]], [[recreation]], [[commerce|commercial]] centers, and [[industrial park]]s, all within one contained development or [[subdivision (land)|subdivision]].
==History== The origins of PUDs in the new American communities can be traced to British movements during the 1950s. The developments in Britain's new communities dealt with the locations of [[industry|industrial]] elements and how they were publicly dictated before building ever began in order to uphold an [[economic base]]. However, in America, privately controlled communities often had to attract industry after the residential sectors had been built and occupied.
The oldest forms of the planned unit development in America appeared shortly after World War II in the [[Levittown]]s and [[Park Forest, Illinois|Park Forest]] developments, as whole communities within the limits and orbits of large metropolitan centers. The first zoning evidence of PUD was created by [[Prince George's County, Maryland]] in 1949. It "permit[ed] the development of a large tract of land as a complete neighborhood unit, having a range of dwelling types, the necessary local shopping facilities and off-street parking areas, parks, playgrounds, school sites, and other community facilities" (Burchell 43). Alexandria, Virginia, in 1952, as an amendment to its city code, provided for a "Community Unit Plan", with the intent to provide for planned community facilities and [[Urban open space|open space]] development with new residential building. One of the first modern uses of the term "planned unit development" appears in San Francisco's code of ordinances in 1962.
==Current definitions== PUD as a regulatory process is a means of land regulation which promotes large scale, unified land development by means of mid-range, realistic programs in chase of physically curable, social and economic deficiencies in land and cityscapes. Where appropriate, this development control promotes: *A mixture of both land uses and dwelling types with at least one of the land uses being regional in nature *The clustering of residential land uses providing public and common open space *Increased administrative discretion to a local professional planning staff while setting aside present land use regulations and rigid plat approval processes *The enhancement of the bargaining process between the developer and government municipalities which in turn strengthens the municipality's site plan review and control over development for potentially increased profits due to land efficiency, multiple land uses, and increased residential densities.
Frequently, PUDs take on a variety of forms ranging from small clusters of houses combined with open spaces to new and developing towns with thousands of residents and various land uses. However, the definition of a PUD does not take into consideration these types of developments unless they fit into a category of size ranging from {{convert|100|to|200|acre}}. In a PUD the property owner owns the land the dwelling sits on.{{citation needed|date=January 2011}}
==Mixtures of land uses== In PUDs, the zoning of districts becomes very different from what was standard under the [[Standard State Zoning Enabling Act|Standard Zoning Enabling Act]]. Historically, the districts were very narrow in type and large in area. Within PUDs, zoning becomes much more integrated with multiple land uses and districts being placed on adjacent land parcels.
Residential properties in PUDs are by far the most numerous and occupy the largest land areas. PUDs tend to incorporate single-family residential uses in proximity to two-family units and multiple-family dwellings to form a larger diversified neighborhood concept. Schools, churches, retirement homes, hospitals, and recreation facilities begin to find their way into residential districts. Residential districts also tend to use the best land in the community and the most favorable sites are protected from commercial and industrial uses.
Grouping shopping districts by service area is a first step in returning to the neighborhood concept. Land is reserved for regional, community, and local shopping clusters with some specific restrictions based on market experience and on what types of business intend to locate at each development. Local shopping districts with sufficient provisions for off-street parking, height restrictions, and traffic control are not frequently found surrounded by residential areas.
Industrial standards now help to reduce the journey for employees to work. Nowadays, there tends to be environmental and performance regulations that cut back on the amount of nuisance to surrounding areas adjacent to industrial districts. With sufficient setbacks, off-street parking, and height regulations, industrial locations adjacent to residential zones are usually looked to as an overall community goal. PUDs do not normally have large numbers of industrial districts, but if so, they tend to be geared more towards light industry.
A '''planned residential unit development (PRUD)''' (sometimes '''planned unit residential development (PURD))''' is a variant form of PUD where common areas are owned by the individual homeowners and not a [[homeowners association]] or other entity. A PURD is considered the same as a PUD for planning commission purposes and allows for flexibility in zoning and civic planning.
=== Maintenance of common areas === In most PUDs, individual owners have full ownership of their homes and buildings, making them the responsible party for maintenance. Governing documents of homeowners associations within PUDs often delegate most of the maintenance responsibilities to the owners, assuming the least amount of responsibility possible.<ref>{{cite web|title=HOA Maintenance Responsibility in Condominiums and Planned Unit Developments|url=http://www.echo-ca.org/article/hoa-maintenance-responsibility-condominiums-and-planned-unit-developments |publisher=ECHO|accessdate=6 August 2014}}</ref>
==Design principles==
===Houses and placement of houses=== Houses in PUDs often include access to a large shared open space surrounding the house as well as a smaller private yard. These large protected open spaces are created by the layout of the buildings and are intended for use by all residents of the developments. Different housing types ([[Single-family detached home|single-family]], [[two-family]], [[multiple-family]]) are often mixed rather than separated as is done in conventional development
===Streets=== [[Street pattern]]s are one of the most important elements in establishing the neighborhood character of a residential community. Most non-PUD development focuses on obtaining maximum [[frontage]] for lot sizes and maximum flow of traffic on all streets. However, in order to dispel the monotony of the typical [[grid plan]] street pattern, PUDs often employ a [[street hierarchy|hierarchy of street types]] based on usage. Local streets serve only residences and have a low traffic volume, while collector streets connect [[local street]]s to arterials, which are the major routes of travel throughout a PUD.
===Sidewalks and pedestrian ways=== Sidewalks and pedestrian ways of PUDs supplement and complement street systems in establishing the character of the neighborhood. Sidewalks are located on at least one side of every street to enable the [[walkability]] of the developments. Circulation systems are provided to link residential groupings, open space areas, schools, and local shopping areas.
===Combining design features=== It is in the ability to design each of these components simultaneously that makes PUDs unique and effective. Each of the elements work together to enhance the whole. This represents a major advantage over traditional zoning practices that force lots to be planned in accordance with broad rules that may allow for some incompatibility.
==References== {{Reflist}} * Burchell, Robert. ''Planned Unit Development: New Communities American Style.'' New Jersey: MacCrellish & Quigley, 1972. * New York City Planning Commission. ''Planned Unit Development''. New York: Planning Department, 1968.

{{distinguish|Egyptian Rape}}
{{Rape}}
'''Rape''' is one of the most common crimes in [[Egypt]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2010/08/06/egyptian-woman-unusual-account-tells-tv-alleged-police-rape/ |title=Egyptian woman goes public about alleged police rape in rare TV interview |publisher=[[Associated Press]] |date=2010-08-06 |accessdate=2013-09-12}}</ref> [[Marital rape]] is not illegal in the country. By 2008, the [[United Nations|U.N.]] quoted [[Egypt's Interior Ministry]]'s figure that 20,000 rapes take place every year, although according to the activist [[Engy Ghozlan]] ([[Egyptian Centre for Women's Rights|ECWR]]), rapes are 10 times higher than the stats given by Interior Ministry, making it 200,000 per year.<ref name="irinnews">{{cite web|url=http://www.irinnews.org/report/76827/egypt-are-attitudes-to-rape-beginning-to-change |title=EGYPT: Are attitudes to rape beginning to change? |publisher=[[IRIN]] |date=2008-02-19 |accessdate=2013-09-12}}</ref> [[Mona Eltahawy]] has also noted the same figure (200,000), and added that this was before the [[Egyptian Revolution of 2011|revolution]], and that today the number is actually higher.<ref>[http://www.escapeartistes.com/2012/04/26/how-safe-is-egypt-after-the-revolution/ How Safe is Egypt After the Revolution?], EscapeArtistes, April 26, 2012</ref>
Rapes have been carried out during festivals and the Egyptian protests, and include the public rapes of women, and female journalists.<ref name="NY post">{{cite web|url=https://nypost.com/2013/07/02/dutch-female-reporter-gang-raped-by-5-men-in-violent-egyptian-protests/ |title=Dutch female reporter gang-raped by 5 men in violent Egyptian protests |publisher=[[NY Post]] |date=2013-07-02 |accessdate=2013-09-12}}</ref>
== Prevalence ==
Rapes are usually not reported in Egypt, due to the fear of social rejection, and culturally it is not accepted.
Rania Hamid from Centre for Egyptian Women’s Legal Assistance (CEWLA) says that no one tells that they have been raped, saying "Girls consider it to be quite enough that a few people know about the rape." Rania Hamid further describes the problem, that even if a girl would reveal that she has been raped, the whole issue would take form of honour, she said that "There are problems of honour. Sometimes a brother or cousin may kill her, saying 'you wanted this, you encouraged this, you’re not honourable, and what is that you are wearing?...' Of course it’s not her fault, but who are you going to tell that to? The girl or society?"<ref name="irinnews"/>
According to the [[United States' Country Reports on Human Rights Practices|US State Department country report]], "[[honour crimes]]" are not actually illegal in Egypt.{{citation needed|date=June 2016}}
Farah Shash, a psychologist explains that young boys are rarely stopped or opposed by their parents for molesting girls publicly, it's because the children always saw the same behavior around them. Shash further adds that "Often, families will just laugh".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/features/2013/08/201381494941573782.html|title=Egypt's sexual assault epidemic|date=14 August 2013|publisher=[[Al Jazeera]]|accessdate=2013-09-17}}</ref> According Seif el-Dawla who runs a center in the country told that "Sexual molestation and harassment ... is routine for women who come across police".
[[Egyptian Centre for Women's Rights]] (ECWR) has called the problem "social cancer" and suggested that dress code is not deterrent at all. [[Egyptian Centre for Women's Rights|ECWR]] carried out a survey in 2008 which found that 83 percent of Egyptian women and 98 percent of foreign women within Egypt had experienced sexual harassment at some time, and only 12% had gone to police for complaining such issue.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://m.arabianbusiness.com/egyptian-jailed-three-years-for-groping-84452.html |title=Egyptian jailed three years for groping |date=21 October 2008}}</ref> Over 62% of Egyptian men admitted harassing women, and 53% of Egyptian men have blamed women for 'bringing it on.'
[[United Nations Entity for Gender Equality]] on May 23, 2013, reported that estimated of 99.3% of Egyptian women said they faced some form of sexual violence.<ref name="edition.cnn.com">{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2013/07/03/opinion/burleigh-rapes-tahrir-square/index.html|title=Gang rape, the dark side of Egypt's protests|date=3 July 2013|publisher=[[CNN]]|accessdate=2013-09-13}}</ref>
In some cases, rape has been connected to religious issues.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.mnnonline.org/article/12056|title=Egyptian police torture and beat believer in attempt to force her reconversion|date=30 December 2008|publisher=[[Mission Network News]]|accessdate=2013-09-12}}</ref> Activists reported that the [[Muslim Brotherhood in Egypt|Muslim Brotherhood]] pays for raping women and beating men.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://s3-eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/pathwaysofempowerment-org-staging/downloads/uncovering_stories_of_sexual_assault_original12854b8f7935685e52600bd699fe8c15.pdf|title=Uncovering Stories of Sexual Assault in the Shadow of The Brothers}}</ref>
== Security forces == {{Expand section|date=January 2016}} There are incidents in which military men had raped a civilian.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2012/04/07/egypt-military-impunity-violence-against-women |title=Egypt: Military Impunity for Violence Against Women|publisher=Human Rights Watch}}</ref> In April 2014, it was reported that the Egyptian police was using rape as a weapon against the political dissidents, in relation to this report, one of the victim had raised the issue during the first judicial hearing, although the victim's complaint was ignored.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/apr/12/egypt-police-rape-dissidents-crackdown-16000-arrested Egyptian police 'using rape as a weapon' against dissident groups | World news | The Observer<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
== Child sexual abuse == {{Expand section|date=January 2016}}
[[File:AgapeGirgis.jpg|150px|thumb|left|Agape Girgis, 13 year old Egyptian girl, abducted from Nahda, el-Ameriya, near Alexandria, on December 23, 2012<ref>[http://www.aina.org/news/20130202195322.htm [[Assyrian International News Agency]] (AINA)]</ref>]]A survey of male and female students at [[Sohag University]] found an overall child sexual abuse prevalence of 29.8%, with the rate for females (37.8%) being higher than that for males (21.2%). Hugging and kissing in a way that disturbed the victim were the most reported type of child sexual abuse. 76.1% of the abuse was not disclosed to another party.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=El Sayed|first1=Khaled|title=Prevalence and pattern of child sexual abuse reported by cross sectional study among the University students, Sohag University, Egypt|journal=Egyptian Journal of Forensic Sciences|date=September 2012|volume=2|issue=3| pages=89–96| url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S2090536X12000287 |accessdate=6 November 2014|doi=10.1016/j.ejfs.2012.05.001}}</ref>
Child rape as a form of punishment has been reported.<ref name="thecommentator">{{cite web|url=http://www.thecommentator.com/article/5027/punishment_rape_in_egypt_by_the_muslim_brotherhood|title=Punishment rape in Egypt by the Muslim Brotherhood - The Commentator|publisher=thecommentator.com|accessdate=2014-09-15}}</ref>
Egypt remains one of the most common countries for forced marriage as well as child marriage, along with Saudi Arabia and Yemen. An Egyptian TV series named ''Burying Girls Alive'', shown on one of the satellite channels during Ramadan, shows an old man simply buying a teenage girl by taking advantage of poverty.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rnw.nl/english/article/child-marriage-legalised-rape|title=Child marriage: legalised rape?|date=19 July 2013|publisher=Radio Netherlands Worldwide|accessdate=2013-09-17}}</ref>
The high rate of rape and abduction of [[Coptic Orthodox Church of Alexandria|Coptic children]] by Islamists has also been documented both during President Morsi's rule and subsequently,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.aina.org/news/20130201192615.htm | last= Abdelmassih | first= Mary |title= Abducted Egyptian Christian Girl Possibly Smuggled to Libya |date= 2013-02-02 |publisher= [[Assyrian International News Agency]] |accessdate=2014-08-19}}</ref> so has [[Persecution of Copts#Abduction and forced conversion of Coptic women|abduction of Coptic minors for the purpose of forced marriage to Muslim men]].<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.aina.org/news/20130202195322.htm | last= Abdelmassih | first= Mary |title= Egyptian Christian Girl, 13, Abducted By Muslims |date= 2013-02-03 |publisher= [[Assyrian International News Agency]] |accessdate=2014-08-19 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20160708215026/http://www.aina.org/news/20130202195322.htm |archivedate= 2016-07-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url= http://csi-usa.org/TellMyMotherIMissHer.pdf |title= The Disappearance, Forced Conversions and Forced Marriages of Coptic Christian Women in Egypt| date= 2012-07-01 |publisher= [[Christian Solidarity International]] |accessdate=2016-07-08 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20160708215413/http://csi-usa.org/TellMyMotherIMissHer.pdf |archivedate= 2016-07-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.foxnews.com/world/2014/06/20/hundreds-egyptian-women-and-girls-kidnapped-forced-into-islam-claims-report.html |title=Hundreds of Egyptian women and girls kidnapped, forced into Islam, claims report| date= 2014-06-20 |publisher= [[Fox News]] |accessdate=2016-07-08 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20160708215927/http://www.foxnews.com/world/2014/06/20/hundreds-egyptian-women-and-girls-kidnapped-forced-into-islam-claims-report.html |archivedate= 2016-07-08}}</ref>
Organised abduction rings, police collusion and payments for each abductee are also alleged.<ref>{{cite news|url= https://www.worldwatchmonitor.org/2017/09/egypt-ex-kidnapper-admits-get-paid-every-copt-christian-girl-bring/ |title=Egypt: ex-kidnapper admits ‘they get paid for every Coptic Christian girl they bring in’ |date= 2017-09-14 |publisher= World Watch Monitor |accessdate=2017-12-25 | archiveurl= https://www.webcitation.org/6vyosZwGR |archivedate= 2017-12-25}}</ref>
== Mass sexual assault == {{main article|Mass sexual assault in Egypt}}
=== During protests === During the 2011 - 2014 [[Timeline of the 2011–present Egyptian civil unrest|Egyptian protests]], rape had been carried out publicly. [[File:Lara Logan crop.jpg|upright|thumb|right|[[Lara Logan]]]] CBS correspondent [[Lara Logan]] revealed in her [[60 Minutes]] program that she and her CBS crew were arrested and detained for one night by the Egyptian Army on 3 February 2011, while covering the [[Egyptian Revolution of 2011|Egyptian Revolution]]. She said the crew was blindfolded and handcuffed at gunpoint, and their driver beaten. They were advised to leave the country, but were later released.<ref name="esquire">{{cite web|last=Kamer|first=Foster|title=Lara Logan's Egypt Interrogation Tell-All|url=http://www.esquire.com/blogs/politics/lara-logan-egypt-5219471|publisher=Esquire}} *{{cite news|title=TIME Exclusive: CBS's Lara Logan and Crew Detained in Cairo As Violence Escalates|url=http://newsfeed.time.com/2011/02/03/time-exclusive-cbss-lara-logan-and-crew-detained-in-cairo-as-violence-escalates|date=3 February 2011|publisher=Time magazine}} *[http://www.charlierose.com/view/interview/11457 Charlie Rose Interview with Lara Logan], see 3:30–4:00, 7 February 2011.</ref> On 15 February 2011, CBS News released a statement that Logan had been beaten and sexually assaulted on 11 February, while covering the celebrations in Tahrir Square following [[Hosni Mubarak]]'s resignation.<ref>{{cite news |last=Stelter |first=Brian |url=http://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/02/15/cbs-lara-logan-suffered-brutal-attack-in-cairo/?scp=5&sq=Lara+Logan&st=nyt |title=CBS Says Lara Logan Suffered 'Brutal' Attack in Cairo |publisher=The New York Times |date=15 February 2011}}</ref> In Logan's own words, they raped her with their hands, while taking photographs with their cellphones. They began pulling her body in different directions, pulling her hair so hard she said it seemed they were trying to tear off chunks of her scalp. Believing she was dying, she was dragged along the square to where the crowd was stopped by a fence, alongside which a group of women were camping. One woman wearing a [[chador]] put her arms around Logan, and the others closed ranks around her, while some men who were with the women threw water at the crowd. A group of soldiers appeared, beat back the crowd with batons, and one of them threw Logan over his shoulder. She was flown back to the U.S. the next day, where she spent four days in the hospital. She was contacted by US president [[Barack Obama]] when she arrived home.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2011/02/15/60minutes/main20032070.shtml |title=Lara Logan Assaulted During Egypt Protests |publisher=CBS News |date=15 February 2011}}</ref> CBS said it remained unclear who the attackers were, and unlikely that any will be prosecuted.
A female 22-year-old Dutch journalist was gang raped by 5 men in the protest.<ref name="NY post"/>
On 3 July 2013, it was reported that about 91 women were raped and sexually abused in [[Tahrir Square]] in 4 days.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2354477/Egypt-protests-2013-NINETY-ONE-women-raped-sexually-abused-Tahrir-Square-4-days.html|title=NINETY-ONE women protesters raped and sexually abused in Tahrir Square in just four days|date=3 July 2013|publisher=Daily Mail|accessdate=2013-09-12}}</ref>
Such incidents don't seem to be opposed by the government or officials, but instead they seemed to have gathered support. Report by [[Nina Burleigh]] quotes Egyptian [[Salafi movement|Salafi]] preacher Ahmad Mahmoud Abdullah, who said that "women protesting in [[Tahrir Square]] have no shame and want to be raped".<ref name="edition.cnn.com"/>
After revolution, about 50% of women have reported more harassment. 44% said that harassment remained is same as it was before, while, over 58% of men surveyed have told that harassment has been increased after revolution.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/en/perspective/features/2013/06/02/Women-in-Egypt-suffer-more-sexual-violence-under-Islamist-rule-.html|title=Women in Egypt suffer more sexual violence under Islamist rule|date=2 June 2013|publisher=Alarabiya|accessdate=2013-09-13}}</ref>
=== Eid al Fitr assaults ===
There were several accounts of a heightened number of sexual assaults and rapes taking place during [[Eid al Fitr]] in 2006 in Egypt, some noting as well the precautions being taken to prevent a recurrence of such problems.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/6106500.stm?lsm |title=Cairo street crowds target women |publisher=BBC News|date=2006-11-01 |accessdate=2013-08-13|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Iqu6VUTY |archivedate=2013-08-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.al-akhbar.com/node/12456 |title=The Widespread Plague of Sexual Harassment in Egypt |publisher=Al Akhbar English |date=2012-09-20 |accessdate=2013-08-11|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6IeLrot6G |archivedate=2013-08-05}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Ali |first=Mohammed |url=http://www.aljadid.com/content/taking-sexual-harassment-social-phenomenon-egypt |title=Taking on Sexual Harassment, a Social Phenomenon in Egypt | Al Jadid Magazine |publisher=Aljadid.com |date=2008-10-21 |accessdate=2013-08-11|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6IeLttWjy |archivedate=2013-08-05}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ikhwanweb.com/article.php?id=1178 |title=Sexual Harassment Takes Center Stage Again in Egypt |publisher=Ikhwanweb |date=2007-07-05 the case of sexual harassment in Cairo |publisher=World Pulse |date=2012-10-29 |accessdate=2013-08-11|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6IeMO837j |archivedate=2013-08-05}}</ref><ref name="Al Arabiya">{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.alarabiya.net/articles/2008/10/05/57724.html |title=Sexual assaults in Egypt mar Eid holiday |publisher=Al Arabiya |date=2008-10-05 |accessdate=2013-08-12|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Iph27t8J |archivedate=2013-08-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite 2012, "The Eid al-Fitr holiday following this year's Ramadan brought its usual share of sexual harassment".<ref>{{cite assaults, 'described Eid al-Fitr as a "season for harassment"',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.egyptindependent.com/news/several-arrested-sexual-harassment-surges-cairo |title=Several arrested as sexual harassment surges in Cairo |publisher=Egypt Independent|date=2012-08-21 |accessdate=2013-08-13|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6IqwFz41J |archivedate=2013-08-13}}</ref> and the harassment|publisher=USA Today|date= 2013-10-26|accessdate=2014-03-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailynewsegypt.com/2013/08/10/victim-of-harassment-killed-in-tanta/ |title=Victim of E news | date= 2014-06-30 | accessdate= 2014-07-22}}</ref> 2014 saw lower rates of attempted harassment, and activists reported women and girls were more confident that assaults would be punished since amendment of the penal code earlier in the year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailynewsegypt.com/2014/07/31/anti-sexual-harassment-initiative-intervenes-35-incidents-eid/ | title= Anti-sexual harassment initiative intervenes in 35 incidents during Eid | publisher= Daily News Egypt|date= 2014-07-31|accessdate= 2014-08-01}}</ref> 6 arrests were reported in Eid.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/en/webtv/reports/2014/07/30/Six-arrested-in-Egypt-for-sexual-harassment-during-Eid.html | title= Six arrested in Egypt over sexual harassment during Eid | work = Al Arabiya | date= 2014-07-30 | accessdate= 2014-08-01}}</ref> In 2015, 141 police reports for sexual harassment were filed during Eid in Cairo.<ref name=CP /> It was claimed the lack of data security or of a support mechanism after reporting hindered confidence, leading to many reports being subsequently withdrawn.<ref name=CP>{{cite web |url=http://www.thecairopost.com/news/160309/inside_egypt/141-sexual-harassment-incidents-reported-in-3-days-during-eid-al-fitr-ncw |title=141 sexual harassment incidents reported in 3 days during Eid {{Other uses|Red flag (disambiguation)}} {{More citations needed|date=January 2009}} [[File:Cornelis Verbeeck, A Naval Encounter between Dutch and Spanish Warships, 156252 original.jpg|thumb|300px|A Naval Encounter between Dutch and Spanish Warships by [[Cornelis Verbeeck]]. c. 1618/1620. A solid red flag, signifying the ship’s intent to engage in combat with a Spanish galleon (left ship), flies at the Dutch warship's [[stern]] (right ship).{{cite web|url=http://www.nga.gov/content/dam/ngaweb/collection/artobject/156252/versions/2014-04-24_artobject_156252.pdf |format=PDF |title=A Naval Encounter |author=Cornelius Verbeeck |website=Nga.gov |accessdate=2016-10-29}}]] The term '''''red flag''''' could mean either a literal [[flag]] used for signaling or, as a [[metaphor]], a sign of some particular problem requiring attention.{{cite web|url=http://i.word.com/idictionary/red%20flag |title=Red Flag | Definition of Red Flag by Merriam-Webster |website=I.word.com |date= |accessdate=2016-10-29}} The earliest citation for "red flag" in the ''[[Oxford English Dictionary]]'' is from 1602 and shows that at that time the flag was used by military forces to indicate that they were preparing for battle.'''1602''' [[Thomas Dekker (writer)|Thomas Dekker]], ''Satiromastix'', ''Wks.'' 1873 I. 233 ″What, dost summon a parlie, my little Drumsticke? tis too late: thou seest my red flag is hung out.″
'''1666''' ''Lond. Gaz.'' No. 91/4 ″That the Red Flag was out, both Fleets in sight of each other, expecting every hour fit weather to Engage.″ The earliest citation of "red flag" in the sense of a warning is dated 1777 and refers to a flag warning of flood.'''1777''' [[Philip Thicknesse]], ''Year's Journey'' I. iii. 23 There is a red flag hoisted gradually higher and higher, as the water flows into the harbour [at Calais]. The term and the expression "to raise the [[red]] flag" come from various usages of real [[flag]]s throughout history. The [[Railway signal#Mechanical signals|semaphore]] red flag (or red light) on railways means an immediate stop, while a red flag is frequently flown by armed forces to warn the public of live fire exercises in progress, and is sometimes flown by ships carrying munitions (in this context it is actually the flag for the letter B in the [[International maritime signal flags|International maritime signal flag alphabet]], a red [[swallowtail (flag)|swallow-tailed flag]]). In many countries a red flag is flown to signify that an outdoor [[shooting range]] is in use. The [[United States Air Force]] refers to its largest annual [[military exercise|exercise]] as [[Red Flag (USAF)|red flag]] operation. Red flags are used for various signals in team sailing races (see [[Racing Rules of Sailing]]). A [[red flag warning]] is a signal of high [[wildfire]] danger and a red flag on the beach warns of dangerous water conditions (double red flags indicate beach closure). Red flags of various designs indicate dangerous wind and wave conditions for mariners. In auto racing, a red flag indicates a stop to the race due to dangerous conditions. A signal of [[Risk|danger]] or a problem can be referred to as a red flag, a usage that originated in the 18th century. The term "red flag" is used, e.g., during screening of communications, and refers to specific words or phrases encountered that might indicate relevance to the case. For example, email [[spam filter]]s make use of such "red flags". ==See also== * [[Racing flags#Red flag|Racing flags § Red flag]] * [[Red Flags Rule]] ==Notes== {{Reflist|group=nb}} ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Communication]] [[Category:Red symbols|Flag, red (signal)]]

{{lead too short|date=January 2012}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2011}}
[[Azerbaijani SSR]] was one of the first republic of Soviet Union that faced the problem of '''[[refugees]] and [[internally displaced persons]]'''. The refugees are ethnic [[Azerbaijanis]] from Armenia and the internally displaced persons are ethnic Azerbaijanis from [[Nagorno-Karabakh]] and the [[Armenian-controlled territories surrounding Nagorno-Karabakh|seven adjacent rayons]] which are controlled by the self-proclaimed [[Nagorno-Karabakh Republic]].
==Refugees from Armenia== {{See also|Azerbaijanis in Armenia}} [[File:Comparison table of armenian azeri kurdish population of armenia.jpg|thumb|280px|Comparison table of Armenian, Azerbaijani and Kurdish population of Armenia.]] According to the 1979 census, Azeris numbered 160,841 and constituted 5.3% of Armenia's population.<ref>{{ru icon}} [http://demoscope.ru/weekly/ssp/sng_nac_79.php?reg=13 All-Soviet Population Census of 1979 - Ethnic Composition in the Republics of the USSR: Armenian SSR]. ''Demoscope.ru''</ref> Civil unrest in Nagorno-Karabakh in 1987 led to Azeris' being often harassed and forced to leave Armenia.<ref name="cornell">{{ru icon}} [http://www.sakharov-center.ru/publications/azrus/az_015.htm The Nagorno-Karabakh Conflict] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110606111926/http://www.sakharov-center.ru/publications/azrus/az_015.htm |date=6 June 2011 }} by Svante Cornell. ''Sakharov-Center.ru''</ref> On 25 January 1988, the first wave of Azeri refugees from Armenia settled in the city of [[Sumgait]].<ref name="cornell"/><ref name="timeline">{{ru icon}} [http://news.bbc.co.uk/hi/russian/news/newsid_3681000/3681079.stm Karabakh: Timeline of the Conflict]. ''BBC Russian''</ref> Another major wave occurred in November 1988<ref name="timeline"/> as Azeris were either expelled by the nationalists and local or state authorities<ref name="barrington">[https://books.google.com/books?id=Jp-5UtoBtFEC After Independence] by Lowell W. Barrington. University of Michigan Press, 2006; p. 231. {{ISBN|0-472-06898-9}}</ref> or fled fearing for their lives.<ref name="unhcr1">[http://www.unhcr.org/refworld/pdfid/3f5f27d14.pdf International Protection Considerations Regarding Armenian Asylum-Seekers and Refugees. United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. Geneva: September 2003]</ref> Violence took place as a result of ethnic conflicts;<ref>[http://www.nmnby.org/pub/0701/15m.html The Unrecognized IV. The Bitter Fruit of the 'Black Garden'] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081120215204/http://www.nmnby.org/pub/0701/15m.html |date=20 November 2008 }} by Yazep Abzavaty. ''Nashe Mnenie''. 15 January 2007. Retrieved 1 August 2008</ref> in November 1988, 25 Azeris were killed, according to Armenian sources (of those 20 in the town of [[Gugark, Armenia|Gugark]]);<ref>{{ru icon}} [http://www.sumgait.info/press/express-chronicle/express-chronicle-910416.htm Pogroms in Armenia: Opinions, Conjecture and Facts]. Interview with Head of the Armenian Committee for National Security Usik Harutyunyan. ''Ekspress-Khronika''. #16. 16 April 1991. Retrieved 1 August 2008</ref> and 217, according to Azerbaijani sources.<ref>[http://www.human.gov.az/?sehife=etrafli&sid=MTIyMTA2MTA4MTIzNjA2Ng==&dil=en Azerbaijan State Commission On Prisoners of War, Hostages and Missing Persons]</ref>
Thus, in 1988–91 the remaining Azeris were forced to flee primarily to Azerbaijan.<ref name="barrington"/><ref>[http://www.unhcr.org/refworld/country,,USCIS,,AZE,4562d8cf2,3ae6a6073,0.html UNHCR U.S. Department of Homeland Security, Citizenship and Immigration Services Country Reports Azerbaijan. The Status of Armenians, Russians, Jews and Other Minorities]</ref><ref>[https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2004/41668.htm Country Reports on Human Rights Practices - 2004: Armenia]. U.S. Department of State</ref> It is impossible to determine the exact population numbers for Azeris in Armenia at the time of the conflict's escalation, since during the 1989 census forced Azeri migration from Armenia was already in progress. UNHCR's estimate is 200,000 persons.<ref name="unhcr1"/>
According to Azerbaijani government at the time of the ceasefire in 1994 there were about 250,000 Azeri refugees from Armenia.<ref name="unhcr.org">[http://www.unhcr.org/4bd7edbd9.html Azerbaijan:Analysis of Gaps in the Protection of Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs). UNHCR. October 2009]</ref> According to the [[Azerbaijani nationality law|1998 Citizenship Law]] they are all eligible for citizenship. By the end of 2001, UNHCR estimated that most of them were believed to have naturalized or be in the process of doing so.<ref name="ReferenceA">[http://www.unhcr.org/refworld/docid/3f5f49fa4.html International Protection Considerations Regarding Azerbaijani Asylum-Seekers and Refugees. UN High Commissioner for Refugees. 2003]</ref>
==Internally displaced persons from Nagorno-Karabakh and the adjacent territories== [[File:Refugeesaz.jpg|300px|thumb|Refugees in Azerbaijan]] During the [[Nagorno-Karabakh War]], territories constituting the former [[NKAO]] region of Azerbaijan and the [[Armenian-controlled territories surrounding Nagorno-Karabakh|seven adjacent rayons]] (some of them partly) were occupied by the Armenian forces. As a result, people had to leave their homes. Azerbaijan now has one of the highest numbers of internally displaced persons (IDPs) per capita in the world.<ref>{{cite web|title=Global Report on Internal Displacement|url=http://www.internal-displacement.org/global-report/grid2017/ |publisher=Internal Displacement Monitoring Centre |accessdate=September 5, 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180901185105/http://www.internal-displacement.org/global-report/grid2017/|archivedate=September 1, 2018}}</ref> The IDPs are presented in all of the 76 administrative districts in Azerbaijan. Initially, most of them lived in tent camps and public buildings such as schools, hostels, and dormitories. Since 2001, the Government increased its efforts to solve IDPs' problems. In 2002, the construction of new settlements started, and by the end of 2007, all tent camps were abolished.<ref name="unhcr.org"/>
The Government of Azerbaijan with the help of the international community has started drafting a Framework Plan for the Return of IDPs to the occupied regions after the settlement of the Nagorno-Karabakh Conflict ([[The Great Return Programme]]).<ref name="unhcr.org"/>
==Other refugees and asylum seekers== In 1944, [[Meskhetian Turks]] were deported en masse from [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]] to [[Central Asia]] by [[Joseph Stalin]]. One of the regions they resettled in was [[Fergana Valley]], [[Uzbekistan]]. In 1989, interethnic violence occurred there triggering an evacuation of Meskhetian Turks from Uzbekistan. This group of refugees in Azerbaijan numbered about 50,000 people. According to the 1998 Citizenship Law, they are all eligible for citizenship. By the end of 2001, [[UNHCR]] estimated that most of them were believed to have naturalized
==Statistics== [[File:Distribution of IDPs in Azerbaijan (2009).jpg|380px|thumb|Distribution of IDPs in Azerbaijan's regions according to the Government of Azerbaijan]]
'''According to''' [[State Committee of Republic of Azerbaijan for Refugees and IDPs|State Committee of Republic of Azerbaijan for Refugees and Internally Displaced Persons]], there were 603,251 IDPs in Azerbaijan in March 2009. The majority live in and around Baku, as well as in Sumgayit. Significant numbers of IDPs also live along the central-southern route of [[Füzuli]]–[[Agdam|Aghdam]]–[[Agjabedi]]–[[Barda, Azerbaijan|Barda]]–[[Mingechevir]]–[[Ganja, Azerbaijan|Ganja]], the northern route of [[Shamakhi]]–[[Ismailli]]–[[Qabala|Gabala]]–[[Sheki, Azerbaijan|Sheki]] and the southern route of [[Sabirabad (city)|Sabirabad]]–[[Saatli]]–[[Imishli]]–[[Beylagan]].<ref name="unhcr.org"/>
==Problems== Although relations between IDPs and the local population are generally amicable and there is a high level of tolerance among the local population, there are instances of conflicts arising due to the special status of IDPs (such as privileged access to employment, government financial assistance, free health services and property ownership privileges).<ref name="unhcr.org"/>

{{Infobox Former Country |native_name = {{my|ဟံသာဝတီ နေပြည်တော်}} |conventional_long_name = Restored Kingdom of Hanthawaddy Pegu |common_name = Hanthawaddy Kingdom |continent = Asia |region = South-East Asia |country = Burma |era = |status = Kingdom |event_start = Founding of Kingdom |year_start = 1740 |date_start = 29 November |event_end = Fall of Kingdom |year_end = 1757 |date_end = 6 May |event1 = War with [[Toungoo Dynasty]] |date_event1 = 1740–1752 |event2 = Rise of Binnya Dala |date_event2 = 1747 |event3 = Invasion of Upper Burma |date_event3 = 1751–1752 |event4 = [[Konbaung-Hanthawaddy War]] |date_event4 = 1752–1757 |p1 = Toungoo Dynasty |flag_p1 = |s1 = Konbaung Dynasty |flag_s1 = Flag of the Alaungpaya Dynasty of Myanmar.svg |image_flag = |flag = |flag_type = |image_coat = |image_map = |symbol = |symbol_type = |image_map_caption = |capital = [[Bago, Burma|Pegu]] (1740–1757) |common_languages = [[Mon language|Mon]] |religion = [[Theravada Buddhism]] |government_type = Monarchy |leader1 = [[Smim Htaw Buddhaketi]] |year_leader1 = 1740–1747 |leader2 = [[Binnya Dala]] |year_leader2 = 1747–1757 |currency = |legislature = }} {{History of Burma}} {{Burmese characters}}
The '''Restored Hanthawaddy Kingdom''' ({{lang-my|ဟံသာဝတီ နေပြည်တော်}}) was the kingdom that ruled [[Lower Burma]] and parts of [[Upper Burma]] from 1740 to 1757. The kingdom grew out of a rebellion by the [[Mon people]], who then formed the majority in Lower Burma, against the [[Bamar|Burman]] [[Toungoo Dynasty]] of [[Inwa|Ava]] in Upper Burma. The rebellion succeeded in restoring the fallen [[Mon language|Mon]]-speaking [[Kingdom of Hanthawaddy]], which ruled Lower Burma from 1287 to 1539. Supported by the [[French colonial empire|French]], the upstart kingdom quickly carved out a space for itself in Lower Burma, and continued its push northward. In March 1752, its forces captured Ava, and ended the 266-year-old Toungoo dynasty.<ref name=geh-211-217/>
A new dynasty called [[Konbaung dynasty|Konbaung]] led by King [[Alaungpaya]] rose in Upper Burma to challenge the southern forces, and went on to conquer all of Upper Burma by December 1753. After Hanthawaddy's invasion of Upper Burma failed in 1754, the kingdom came unglued. Its leadership in self-defeating measures killed off the Toungoo royal family, and persecuted ethnic Burmans in the south, both of which only strengthened Alaungpaya's hand.<ref name=vbl-202-206/> In 1755, Alaungpaya invaded Lower Burma. Konbaung forces captured the [[Irrawaddy delta]] in May 1755, the French defended port of [[Thanlyin]] in July 1756, and finally the capital [[Bago, Burma|Pegu]] in May 1757.
The fall of Restored Hanthawaddy was the beginning of the end of Mon people's centuries-old dominance of Lower Burma. Konbaung armies' reprisals forced thousands of Mons to flee to [[Ayutthaya Kingdom|Siam]].<ref name=tmu-97>Myint-U (2006): 97</ref> By the early 19th century, assimilation, inter-marriage, and mass migration of Burman families from the north had reduced the Mon population to a small minority.<ref name=vbl-202-206/>
==Rise of southern kingdom== The southern rebellion was the most serious threat to the Toungoo Dynasty, which was already on its last legs. Its weak kings had been unable to stem the constant raids on the [[Chindwin river]] valley by the [[Meitei people|Meiteis]] since 1724, or put down a nagging rebellion in [[Lan Na]] in the east since 1727. The Ava-appointed governor at Pegu was assassinated on {{OldStyleDate|29 November|1740|18 November}} by the local court.<ref name=vbl-1984-215>Lieberman 1984: 215</ref> The court elected a [[Mon language|Mon]]-speaking Burman of royal lineage with the Mon title of [[Smim Htaw Buddhaketi]], as king of Hanthawaddy on {{OldStyleDate|8 December|1740|27 November}}.<ref name=Hmn3>Hmannan Vol. 3 (1829): 372–373</ref><ref group=note>(Lieberman 1984: 215–216): His forces attacked Syriam on {{OldStyleDate|15 December|1740|4 December}}, a week after his accession.</ref>
In 1742, the Hanthawaddy forces started raiding annually up the [[Irrawaddy river]] as far as Ava. By 1745, Hanthawaddy controlled much of Lower Burma, and parts of Upper Burma up to [[Prome]] and [[Toungoo]].<ref name=geh-211-217>Harvey (1925): 211–217</ref> (The new kingdom did not control the northern Tenasserim coast. The rulers of [[Martaban]] (Mottama) and [[Tavoy]] (Dawei) sought and received Siamese protection.)
The low grade warfare continued until November 1751 when [[Binnya Dala]], who succeeded Smim Htaw as king in 1747, launched a full-scale invasion of Upper Burma. The Hanthawaddy armies gradually advanced north, and finally sacked the capital city of Ava in March 1752. The royal family was deported to Pegu. Mistakenly thinking that Upper Burma had been won, the Hanthawaddy leadership prematurely returned to Pegu, leaving only a third of the forces led by Gen. [[Dalaban]] to mop up the final resistance in upcountry Burma.<ref name=geh-211-217/>
==Fall== {{Main|Konbaung-Hanthawaddy War}} The inevitable Burman resistance came swiftly. In March 1752, a village headman of [[Shwebo|Moksobo]] named Aung Zeya founded the [[Konbaung Dynasty]] with the title of [[Alaungpaya]] to resist the Mon occupation. Alaungpaya rapidly gained a following from all over Upper Burma. By December 1752, he had reconquered all of Upper Burma north of Ava, and the city itself a year later. In March 1754, Binnya Dala invaded Upper Burma with the entire army. The invasion went well at first, laying siege to Ava and advancing deep into upcountry but ultimately faltered, driven back with heavy losses.
Following the defeat, the leadership of Hanthawaddy escalated its "self-defeating" policies of ethnic polarization in the south. It executed all Avan captives, including the last king of Toungoo, and began requiring all Burmans in the south to wear an earring with a stamp of the Pegu heir-apparent and to cut their hair in Mon fashion as a sign of loyalty.<ref name=vbl-202-206>Lieberman (2003): 202–206</ref>
In 1755, Alaungpaya began the southern push, capturing the [[Irrawaddy delta]] in April and Dagon (now [[Yangon]]) in May. The [[French colonial empire|French]] defended port city of [[Syriam]] (Thanlyin) was taken only after a 14-month siege in July 1756. With French support cut off, the end of the kingdom followed. The capital Pegu fell on 6 May 1757.<ref name=app-166-169>Phayre (1883): 166–169</ref>
==Legacy== The fall of the kingdom was the end of independence for the Mon people as well as their centuries-old dominance of Lower Burma. Konbaung armies' indiscriminate sacking of the low country forced thousands of Mons to flee to [[Ayutthaya Kingdom|Siam]].<ref name=tmu-97/> Ethnic Burman families from the north also began settling in the delta. By the early 19th century, assimilation and inter-marriage had reduced the Mon population to a small minority.<ref name=vbl-202-206/>

{{about|the human disease|stereotypies in non-human animals|Stereotypy (non-human)}} {{distinguish|Stereotype|Stereotypic movement disorder}} A '''stereotypy''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|s|t|ɛr|i|ə|ˌ|t|aɪ|p|i|,_|ˈ|s|t|ɪər|-|,_|-|i|oʊ|-}},{{refn|{{OxfordDictionaries.com|accessdate=2016-01-21|Stereotypy}}}}{{refn|{{MerriamWebsterDictionary|accessdate=2016-01-21|Stereotypy}}}} {{respell|STERR|ee|oh|ty|pee}} or {{respell|STEER|ee|oh|ty|pee}}) is a repetitive or ritualistic movement, posture, or utterance. Stereotypies may be simple movements such as body rocking, or complex, such as self-caressing, crossing and uncrossing of legs, and marching in place. They are found in people with [[intellectual disabilities]], [[autism spectrum disorder]]s, [[tardive dyskinesia]] and [[stereotypic movement disorder]], but may also be encountered in neurotypical individuals as well.<ref>{{vcite journal |author=Jankovic J |title=Differential diagnosis and etiology of tics |journal=Adv Neurol |date=2001 |volume=85 |pages=15–29 |pmid=11530424}}</ref> Studies have shown stereotypies associated with some types of [[schizophrenia]].<ref>{{vcite journal |author=Pedro BM, Pilowsky LS, Costa DC, ''et al.'' |title=Stereotypy, schizophrenia and dopamine D2 receptor binding in the basal ganglia |journal=Psychol Med |volume=24 |issue=2 |pages=423–9 |year=1994 |month=May |pmid=8084937|doi=10.1017/s0033291700027392 }}</ref> [[Frontotemporal dementia]] is also a common neurological cause of repetitive behaviors and stereotypies.<ref name="Mateen FJ, Josephs KA 2009 1237–40">{{cite journal |vauthors=Mateen FJ, Josephs KA | title=The clinical spectrum of stereotypies in frontotemporal lobar degeneration | journal=Movement Disorders | volume=24 | issue=8 | pages=1237–40 |date=June 2009 | pmid=19412926 | doi=10.1002/mds.22555}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Mendez MF, Shapira JS |title=The spectrum of recurrent thoughts and behaviors in frontotemporal dementia |journal=CNS Spectr |volume=13 |issue=3 |pages=202–8 |date=March 2008 |pmid=18323753 |url= http://www.cnsspectrums.com/aspx/articledetail.aspx?articleid=1460}}</ref> Several causes have been hypothesized for stereotypy, and several treatment options are available.<ref name=Singer>{{vcite journal |author=Singer HS |title=Motor stereotypies |journal=Semin Pediatr Neurol |volume=16 |issue=2 |pages=77–81 |year=2009 |pmid=19501335 |doi=10.1016/j.spen.2009.03.008 |url= http://m.hopkinsmedicine.org/neurology_neurosurgery/specialty_areas/pediatric-neurology/conditions/motor-stereotypies/motor-stereotypies.pdf |format= PDF}}</ref>
Stereotypy is sometimes called ''[[stimming]]'' in autism, under the hypothesis that it self-stimulates one or more senses.<ref name=Nind/> Related terms include [[punding]] and (more colloquially) ''tweaking'' to describe repetitive behavior that is a side effect of some drugs.<ref name=Weisheit/>
Among people with [[frontotemporal lobar degeneration]], more than half (60%) had stereotypies. The time to onset of stereotypies in people with frontotemporal lobar degeneration may be years (average 2.1 years).<ref name="Mateen FJ, Josephs KA 2009 1237–40"/>
==Distinction from tics== Like [[tic]]s, stereotypies are patterned and periodic, and are made worse by fatigue, stress, and anxiety. Unlike tics, stereotypies usually begin before the age of three, involve more of the body, are more rhythmic and less random, and are associated more with engrossment in another activity rather than premonitory urges. Examples of early tics are things like blinking and throat clearing, while arm flapping is a more common stereotypy. Stereotypies do not have the ever-changing, waxing and waning nature of tics, and can remain constant for years. Tics are usually suppressible for brief periods; in contrast, children rarely consciously attempt to control a stereotypy, although they can be distracted from one.<ref name=Singer/><ref name=Gilbert>{{vcite journal |author=Muthugovindan D, Singer H |title=Motor stereotypy disorders |journal=Current Opinion in Neurology |volume=22 |issue=2 |pages=131–6 |year=2009 |pmid=19532036 |doi=10.1097/WCO.0b013e328326f6c8 }}</ref>
==Proposed causes== There are several possible explanations for stereotypy, and different stereotyped behaviors may have different explanations. A popular explanation is [[stimming]], which hypothesizes that a particular stereotyped behavior has a function related to sensory input. Other explanations include hypotheses that stereotypy discharges tension or expresses frustration, that it communicates a need for attention or reinforcement or sensory stimulation, that it is learned or neuropathological or some combination of the two, or that it is normal behavior with no particular explanation needed.<ref name=Nind>{{vcite journal |author=Nind M, Kellett M |title=Responding to individuals with severe learning difficulties and stereotyped behaviour: challenges for an inclusive era |journal=Eur J Spec Needs Educ |date=2002 |volume=17 |issue=3 |pages=265–82 |doi=10.1080/08856250210162167 }}</ref>
==Associated terms==
'''[[Punding]]''' is a term that was coined originally to describe complex prolonged, purposeless, and stereotyped behavior in chronic [[amphetamine]] users;<ref name=Weisheit>{{vcite report |author=Weisheit RA |url=http://icjia.state.il.us/public/pdf/ResearchReports/METHAMPHETAMINE%20AND%20VIOLENCE%20IN%20ILLINOIS%20062009.pdf |title=Methamphetamine and violence in Illinois |format=PDF |publisher=Illinois Criminal Justice Information Authority |accessdate=2009-12-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100816114947/http://www.icjia.state.il.us/public/pdf/ResearchReports/METHAMPHETAMINE%20AND%20VIOLENCE%20IN%20ILLINOIS%20062009.pdf |archivedate=2010-08-16 |df= }}</ref> it was later described in [[Parkinson's disease]].<ref>{{vcite journal |author=Evans AH, Katzenschlager R, Paviour D ''et al'' |title=Punding in Parkinson's disease: its relation to the dopamine dysregulation syndrome |journal=Mov Disord |date=2004 |volume=19 |issue=4 |pages=397–405 |pmid=15077237 |doi=10.1002/mds.20045 }}</ref> Punding is a compulsion to perform repetitive mechanical tasks, such as sorting, collecting, or assembling and disassembling common items.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Fernandez HH, Friedman JH |title=Punding on L-dopa |journal=Mov. Disord. |volume=14 |issue=5 |pages=836–8 |date=September 1999 |pmid=10495047 | doi = 10.1002/1531-8257(199909)14:5<836::AID-MDS1018>3.0.CO;2-0 }}</ref> Punding may occur in individuals with Parkinson's disease treated with dopaminergic agents such as [[L-DOPA]].<ref>{{cite journal |author=Jankovic J |title=Motor fluctuations and dyskinesias in Parkinson's disease: clinical manifestations |journal=Mov. Disord. |volume=20 Suppl 11 |issue= |pages=S11–6 |year=2005 |pmid=15822109 |doi=10.1002/mds.20458}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=O'Sullivan SS, Evans AH, Lees AJ |title=Dopamine dysregulation syndrome: an overview of its epidemiology, mechanisms and management |journal=CNS Drugs |volume=23 |issue=2 |pages=157–70 |year=2009 |pmid=19173374 |doi=10.2165/00023210-200923020-00005}}</ref>
'''Tweaking''' is a slang term for compulsive or repetitive behavior; it refers to someone exhibiting pronounced symptoms of [[methamphetamine]] or amphetamine use.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Buxton JA, Dove NA |title=The burden and management of crystal meth use |journal=CMAJ |volume=178 |issue=12 |pages=1537–9 |date=June 2008 |pmid=18519899 |pmc=2396355 |doi=10.1503/cmaj.071234}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |url= http://www.justice.gov/dea/programs/forensicsci/microgram/mg0205/mg0205.html |title= Selected Intelligence brief: methamphetamine myths |journal= U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration |volume= XXXVIII |issue= 2 |date= February 2005 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101017110841/http://www.justice.gov/dea/programs/forensicsci/microgram/mg0205/mg0205.html |archivedate= 2010-10-17 |df= }} Reprinted with permission from the NDIC Narcotics Digest Weekly 2005;4(2):1</ref>
==In animals== {{Main|Stereotypy (non-human)}} <!--detail moved to Stereotypy (non-human)--> Stereotypies also occur in non-human animals. It is considered an [[List of abnormal behaviours in animals|abnormal behavior]] and is sometimes seen in [[Captivity (animal)|captive animals]], particularly those held in small enclosures with little opportunity to engage in more normal behaviors. These behaviors may be maladaptive, involving self-injury or reduced reproductive success, and in laboratory animals can confound behavioral research.<ref name="garner mason">{{vcite journal |title=Evidence for a relationship between cage stereotypies and behavioural disinhibition in laboratory rodents |author=Garner JP, Mason GJ |journal=Behav Brain Res |date=2002 |volume=136 |issue=1 |pages=83–92 |doi=10.1016/S0166-4328(02)00111-0 |pmid=12385793 }}</ref> Examples of stereotypical behaviors include pacing, rocking, swimming in circles, excessive sleeping, self-mutilation (including feather picking and excessive grooming), and mouthing cage bars. Stereotypies are seen in many species, including [[primate]]s, birds, and [[Carnivora|carnivore]]s. Up to 40% of elephants in zoos display stereotypical behaviors.<ref name="elephants">{{vcite news |title=Elephant deaths at zoos reignite animal debate |author=Stern A |agency=Reuters |url=http://www.elephants.com/media/MSNBC_2_28_05.htm |accessdate=2006-05-30 |date=2005-02-28 }}</ref> Stereotypies are well known in [[stable]]d [[horse]]s, usually developing as a result of being confined, particularly with insufficient exercise. They are colloquially called [[stable vices]]. They present a [[horse care|management]] issue, not only leading to facility damage from chewing, kicking, and repetitive motion, but also lead to health consequences for the animal if not addressed.<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.extension.umn.edu/distribution/livestocksystems/DI8538.pdf |author=Christie, Julie Christie, |title=Horse Behavior and Stable Vices |work=University of Minnesota Extension |year=2008 |publisher=Regents of the University of Minnesota |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111102165506/http://www.extension.umn.edu/distribution/livestocksystems/DI8538.pdf |archivedate=2011-11-02 |df= }}</ref>
Stereotypical behaviors are thought to be caused ultimately by artificial environments that do not allow animals to satisfy their normal behavioral needs. Rather than refer to the behavior as abnormal, it has been suggested that it be described as "behavior indicative of an abnormal environment."<ref name="primate newsletter">{{vcite journal |author=Davis E, Down N, Garner J ''et al'' |title=Stereotypical behavior: a LAREF discussion |url=http://www.brown.edu/Research/Primate/lpn43-4.pdf |format=PDF |journal=Lab Primate Newsl |date=2004 |volume=34 |issue=4 |pages=3–4 |accessdate=2009-12-21 }}</ref> Stereotypies are correlated with altered behavioral response selection in the [[basal ganglia]].<ref name="garner mason" /> As stereotypies are frequently viewed as a sign of psychological distress in animals, there is also an [[animal welfare]] issue involved.
Stereotypical behavior can sometimes be reduced or eliminated by [[environmental enrichment (neural)|environmental enrichment]], including larger and more stimulating enclosures, training, and introductions of stimuli (such as objects, sounds, or scents) to the animal's environment. The enrichment must be varied to remain effective for any length of time. Housing social animals with other members of their species is also helpful. But once the behavior is established, it is sometimes impossible to eliminate due to alterations in the brain.<ref name="primate newsletter" />

Retrieved on November 30, 2010. * [http://www.aps.uoguelph.ca/~gmason/StereotypicAnimalBehaviour/library.shtml Photo & video library of stereotypic behavior in captive animals ]

{{infobox organization |name = Tellus Institute |image = Logo Tellus Institute.png |size = |abbreviation = |formation = 1976 |type = [[Nonprofit organization|Non-profit research]] and policy organization |headquarters = [[Boston]], [[United States]] |leader_title = President |leader_name = [[Paul Raskin]] |key_people = | revenue = $772,255<ref name="Ratings">{{cite web | url=http://990s.foundationcenter.org/990_pdf_archive/141/141589922/141589922_201612_990.pdf | title=Tellus Institute Inc. | date=13 November 2017 | website=Foundation Center | accessdate=27 July 2018 }}</ref> | revenue_year = 2016 | expenses = $2,003,436<ref name="Ratings" /> | expenses_year = 2016 |website = [http://www.tellus.org/ www.tellus.org] }} The '''Tellus Institute''' is a non-profit research and policy organization based in [[Boston, Massachusetts]]. Its mission is to advance the transition to a sustainable, equitable, and humane global civilization. The Tellus Institute was founded in 1976 by [[Paul Raskin]], Richard Rosen, Stephen Bernow, John Stutz, and David Nichols for the purpose of research on resource and environmental strategies. Dr. Paul Raskin is the President of the Institute. Initially called the Energy Systems Research Group (ESRG), the Institute adopted its current name in 1990.
==History== Since 1976, Tellus has conducted over 3,500 resource management and environmental strategy projects throughout the world.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.tellus.org/ | title=Our vision, our work | last= | first= | date= | website=Tellus Institute | accessdate=27 July 2018 }}</ref> The Institute is well known in the environmental strategies domain for its many studies on state and municipality recycling programs,<ref>{{cite web|title=Economic & Environmental Benefits of Beverage Container Recycling: The Case for Updating Massachusetts’ Bottle Bill|url=http://www.bottlebill.org/assets/pdfs/campaigns/massachusetts/1998-EconEnviroBenefits.pdf|accessdate=14 May 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Comparison of System Costs and Materials Recovery Rates: Implementation of Universal Single Stream Recycling With and Without Beverage Container Deposits - Draft Report|url=http://www.anr.state.vt.us/dec/wastediv/solid/documents/DRAFT-ReportToANR-4MAR2013.pdf|accessdate=14 May 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Michigan Bottle Bill - A Final Report to: Michigan Great Lakes Protection Fund|url=http://www.michigan.gov/documents/deq/deq-whm-BottleBillRpt-Tellus_255247_7.pdf|accessdate=14 May 2013}}</ref> including its 1992 Packaging study,<ref>{{cite web | url=http://infohouse.p2ric.org/ref/01/00047/7-10.htm | title=Tellus Packaging Study | last= | first= | date= | website=Pollution Prevention Infohouse | accessdate=27 July 2018 }}</ref> the 2008 Assessment of Options for Massachusetts' Solid Waste Master Plan,<ref>{{cite web|title=Assessment of Materials Management Options for the MA Solid Waste Master Plan Review|url=http://www.tellus.org/pub/Final_Report-Materials_Management_Options_for_MA_SW_Master_Plan_Review_-_With_Appendices_-_12-08.pdf|accessdate=14 May 2013}}</ref> and the Preliminary Analysis of the Costs and Benefits of Bottle Bills study done for the US EPA.<ref>{{cite web|title=Is a National Bottle Bill Worthwhile?|url=http://www.recyclingtoday.com/Article.aspx?article_id=18077|accessdate=14 May 2013}}</ref>
Through the years Tellus has created numerous scientific tools and reports in many different areas, including energy, water, [[sustainable communities]], [[corporate social responsibility]], and climate change; however, since 2005 the Institute has shifted its focus to developing a [[Great Transition]] vision for a sustainable future.
==Research and programs== The main body of Tellus' current research specializes in the application of quantitative analysis to the development of possible future scenarios.
Tellus has also launched a number of subsidiary working groups and research programs:
*'''The [[Global Scenario Group]] (GSG)''' was convened in 1995 in order to compile a set of possible scenarios for global development in the twenty-first century. Its goal was to identify a sustainable and equitable future within this set of scenarios and to isolate the policies, actions, and human choices required to achieve this scenario. Its findings indicated that an environmentally sustainable, socially equitable future —which the GSG termed a "Great Transition"—was possible. The GSG’s work culminated with the 2002 publication of ''Great Transition: The Promise and Lure of the Times Ahead''.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.greattransition.org/gt-essay | title=GT Essay | last= | first= | date= | website=Great Transition Initiative | accessdate=27 July 2018 }}</ref> Paul Raskin led the GSG, which consisted of more than 20 environmental scholars from throughout the globe. Scenarios developed by the GSG have informed the [[United Nations Environment Programme]]’s Global Environment Outlook series,<ref>{{cite web|title=Global Environment Outlook Scenario Framework: Background Paper for UNEP's Third Global Environment Outlook Report|url=http://www.unep.org/geo/GEO3/pdfs/GEO_ScenarioFramework.pdf|accessdate=15 May 2013}}</ref> as well as other international and national vision studies. *'''The [[Great Transition#Great Transition Initiative|Great Transition Initiative]] (GTI)''' was formed in 2003 to re-channel the momentum of the GSG. Its mandate is to continue scenario development, disseminate the Great Transition vision to a larger audience, and build a network of GTI members. It was relaunched in April 2014 as an online journal and discussion network devoted to vision and praxis around a progressive global transformation. *'''Corporation 20/20''' is an initiative of Tellus focused on [[corporate social responsibility]]. Its mission is to develop and advocate the redesign of corporations so that business is guided by social purpose as well as financial gain. Co-founded in 2004 by Allen White, Vice President of Tellus, and Marjorie Kelly, co-founder and former editor of ''Business Ethics'' magazine, Corporation 20/20 hosts a forum of leading thinkers, practitioners, and advocates who work to construct alternate visions of the corporate structure, which it then disseminates into the corporate community. *'''The [[Global Reporting Initiative]]''', founded by [[Ceres (organization)]] and Tellus Vice President Allen White, had the goal of developing and disseminating a standardized framework for sustainability reporting. Now an autonomous organization based in Amsterdam, the GRI's framework has become the de facto international standard used by over 1,200 companies for corporate reporting on environmental, social and economic performance. *'''The Global Initiative for Sustainability Ratings (GISR)''' is an initiative launched by Ceres and Tellus in 2011 whose goal is to develop an independent, standardized framework for sustainability ratings. *'''Boston Scenario Project''' was initiated in 2005 as a process for developing local scenarios for the Boston metropolitan region that mirror the global-scale scenarios described in the Great Transition essay. The project seeks to reconcile worldwide effects with local actions in order to envision a future of sustainability, pluralism, justice, and global responsibility for the Boston region, which would also contribute to worldwide sustainability and equity. The Boston Scenario Project is coordinated by James Goldstein, Tellus Senior Fellow.
==Tools== Tellus developed and uses a series of software programs in its research. These programs were designed for strategic planning and [[scenario analysis]], allowing the user to create, evaluate, and compare alternative futures based on current data and hypothetical trends. Long range Energy Alternatives Planning (LEAP) System software facilitates energy-environment planning; [[Weap|WEAP]], water planning; WastePlan, solid waste planning; and PoleStar, sustainability planning.
==Selected publications== *Gerst, Michael, Paul Raskin, and Johan Rockström. "Contours of a Resilient Global Future." ''Sustainability'' 6, no. 1 (2014): 123-135, http://www.mdpi.com/2071-1050/6/1/123. *Raskin, Paul. "A Great Transition?: Where We Stand." ''Great Transition Initiative''. October 2014. http://www.greattransition.org/publication/a-great-transition-where-we-stand. *Raskin, Paul. "Game On: The Basis for Hope in a Time of Despair." ''GTI Perspective Series''. Boston: Tellus Institute, 2013. Available at http://www.gtinitiative.org/documents/GameOn.htm. *Raskin, Paul. ''Journey to Earthland: The Great Transition to Planetary Civilization''. Boston: Tellus Institute, 2016. Available at http://www.greattransition.org/publication/journey-to-earthland. *Raskin, Paul. ''World Lines: Pathways, Pivots, and the Global Futures''. Boston: Tellus Institute, 2006. Available at http://www.gtinitiative.org/documents/PDFFINALS/16WorldLines.pdf. *Raskin, Paul, Tariq Banuri, Gilberto Gallopín, Pablo Gutman, Al Hammond, Robert Kates, and Rob Swart. ''Great Transition: The Promise and Lure of the Times Ahead''. Boston: Stockholm Environment Institute, 2002. Available at http://www.greattransition.org/gt-essay. *White, Allen. "Chapter 7: Reinventing the Corporation." ''State of the World 2012: Moving Toward Sustainable Prosperity''. Washington, DC: Island Press, 2012. Available at http://www.tellus.org/tellus/publication/reinventing-the-corporation.
